Well, I have internet access, and it's a beautiful day.

-Nick

entry.title: Blizzcon 2009 Part 2: Gender
entry.content:
Part 1 was my form of gushing, and it was right to start this series with giving the immediate context: for a large number of people, including myself, Blizzard is awesome.

But problems deserve to be the first thing addressed.  I wouldn't feel right putting this segment (and the next one, Race) at the end of the sequence, as if they were appendices.  These sorts of thoughts are central to my perceptions of Blizzard properties, whether they like it or not.
So, it was revealed a year or so ago that Diablo 3, for the first time in the series, would let you choose between male and female avatars for each class.  This was striking.

Before this announcement, when the (male) Barbarian class was unveiled, I gave a whoop of joy.  He's old.  This is Phoenix on the Sword Conan meets The Light Fantastic Cohen.  He may very well be the same Barbarian of Diablo 2, thirty or forty years on, having failed to die so many times in such incredible circumstances that he's no longer sure if he knows how.  He should be raising barns to house his children, but the call for heroes finds him on the side of a mountain, roasting a bear, and he does not even consider not facing the KINGS OF THE DEVILS yet again.



Sweeeet...

Then the female Barbarian was revealed, and I was even more overjoyed.



It has been said that pop culture's portrayal of "bad-ass" girls ranges from full-bodied objectification to spritely paedophilia, and that they should look more like this female shot-put champion:


And the female Barbarian is that.  She's not perfect: a slight she-hulk vibe persists, with the big hair and the dominatrix sexuality and everything.  But she's built and dressed as unapologetically as her male counterpart,  to crush her enemies, see them driven before her, and...well, the point is, she's an Awesome Woman Kicking Ass, just like the game!

I still mean to play that one...

And yes, let's switch games for a moment.

The tall and lissome Tricia Helfer was announced as the voice talent portraying Kerrigan in Starcraft 2.  This was revealed with mild fanfare, and a milder reaction.

Helfer was catapulted to the heights nerd-recognizability for portraying the the character of Number 6 on Battlestar Galactica, a crazed sexpot hallucination, a psychotic inhuman thing that takes over your life, won't stop talking about children and being together forever, which you're always either fucking or running from in terror.

So no, not the most progressive of roles.  Is Kerrigan an improvement?

Maybe.

See, there were three female characters in Starcraft: the unnamed dropship pilots (you know, like in Aliensno other intellectual property I know of), the unnamed Valkyrie (get it?!) fighter-jet pilots, and Sarah Kerrigan, special ops badass, abandoned by her allies to the evil aliens, shaped into a weapon of fear and horror, who betrayed and consumed her own hive-mind and became the post-human leader of a non-human army.

(Amusingly, this later became the exact same story of Arthas the Lich King, current big bad of World of Warcraft.  Behind every male boss-monster...)

Oh, and before someone bothers to correct me, the game's expansion, Brood War, added a third female: the Medic, also unnamed, who had no weapon, but just followed the testosterone-dripping marines around at a respectful distance, supporting and tending to them.  Yeah, I know.

Anyway, Brood War ends with Kerrigan's apotheosis, which comes after a rejection of the one person (okay, it's a man) who might have convinced her to not try to consume the universe.  Paraphrasing, her parting shot is "Gentlemen, prepare to be fucked."  She's another smothering, all-encompassing trans-female villain, in the vein of System Shock's SHODAN.

They've made her a life-size statue, which was at the convention, complete with glowing eyes, wing-like scythe claws, and shapely ass.  I refused to take a picture of it, because I don't masturbate to The Guyver with a reptile-skin glove, and but I did take this picture of a piece in the art gallery which, I think, depicts her in a later stage of "evolution" (boy do sci-fi games love to misuse that word).



What an awesome picture!  She is unlike any other alien form, and is holding a skull and...contemplating?  Did she know him, Horatio?  Does she remember Kerrigan?  Does she ever regret her irreversible path of vengeance?  Forget the pre-civilized Barbarian.  This Kerrigan is post-civilized, post-biological...post-everything!  An egotist so driven and single-minded that the universe may break before she does.  She's Foyle from The Stars My Destination meets Dave from 2001.

But this is my wishful thinking.  I don't really know if that's Kerrigan, or some other unannounced character.  In statue form, in all the cutscenes and promotional pictures, she is slim and athletic, yet quite feminine.  Why?  Because at least 80% of Blizzard's customers are male, and the other 20% are their wives and girlfriends.  Because one of the eight principles is "Embrace your inner geek," and in genderless English, "geek" is a clearly masculine word.

-Nick

entry.title: Blizzcon 2009 Part 1: Metal
entry.content:
[Edited to add pictures, and make my final point clearer.  I accidentally published this a bit early...]

Let's start at the end.

It's Saturday night.  Casino-like, the permanent twilight of the cavernous (actually, caverns wished they had it this good) Anaheim convention center destroys all sense of time more precise than "I'm so tired, it should be night-time."  And the impression is of a strangely decoration-free casino, with comfortable but subdued slot machines that use keyboards instead of levers, and food so over-priced you'll be forgiven for wondering whether something catastrophic has happened to the world since you walked in, whether outside this shaded oasis people are stabbing each other with sharpened spoons for the last can of baked beans.

Collect three and turn them for another day of subsistence.



By this time, I had seen all I was going to of the games themselves, and had been annoyed enough at the various vendor stalls getting in the way (who is Felicia Day and why are her legions of fans obstructing my path to the Diablo 3 demo?).  I resolved to sit in hall D until the closing ceremony started.
People filter in continuously.  The hall has 12,000 seats, and it's standing room only over an hour before the show starts.  After all, there all over 20,000 more people than that attending, though no doubt some have left early.

Losers.

Level 80 Elite Tauren Chieftain takes the stage and does their PG-13 set.  Samwise, the singer, jokes that the band is in no danger of being paid for their music, gushes about the man he's opening for, and leads duelling group war-cries from people who self-identify as "Horde" or "Alliance."

(I put the terms in quotes to hide the fact that I joined in.  In my defense, if you're not familiar with the story of World of Warcraft, it's that the white people made friends with the "nice" other races, then prosecuted bigoted wars of extermination against the "bad" ones.  So as I see it, you can be a racist, or you can prefer the Horde.)

He jokes that they're tired of changing their level as Blizzard makes new expansions, so in protest, they're change it into a symbol.  He then jokes about how many people in the audience are too young to get the joke.

It's fun.  Cute.  The lyrics scroll on the displays, so we can see how clever (ahem) they are.

They leave.  Darkness reigns unchecked for a bit.  People settle in, relax a bit.  It's been a long day.

Then, Ozzy Ozbourne takes the stage.  

"Are you ready to go fucking wild?!!"

After only a small surprised hesitation, I answer lustily in the affirmative.



Two minutes later I've gotten up from my seat and have walked as far forward as I can before meeting the crush of other true believers that said to themselves "This isn't a lecture: I should stand up, the better to jump and scream and wave my arms about.  I should walk forward, the better to be deafened."

We did our best, we happy few 30 front rows, center aisle.  We did our best to jump, scream, wave our arms.  We did our best not to look behind us or to either side, to see people watching with a level of pleased interest and mild arousal usually reserved for tennis matches rather than OZZY OSBOURNE IS RIGHT FUCKING THERE SINGING MR CROWLEY WHAT THE FUCK IS WRONG WITH YOU PEOPLE

On the monitors, he sometimes seemed stunned with disbelief.  He knows, and we know now, that he can still rock.  But even the true believers, we mesomorphic elite of the elite did our best to fill his vision, frequently fall short of the level of "fucking insanity" expected.  He leads us in claps, hand waves, fist pumps, "Oi!"s.  It's like the world's greatest Richard Simmons video, except it's half-way to the world's saddest rock concert.



He doesn't remember his drummer's name.  But he, and all the other assembled instrumentalists, do their level best to rock the fucking planet.  For them, it's a night with Ozzy.  For Ozzy...well, they say he's a fan.  They say he plays World of Warcraft to a degree that would be called unhealthy, if it weren't for the fact that his wife says it keeps him from hitting alcohol as much.  

(We're learning to make things that make better drugs than drugs do.)

He's doing this as a favor.  He doesn't phone it in.  He's great.  It's great.  A perfect end to any day.

A telling end in this specific context, due to one particular part.  But first, two other disparate points with, I'm convinced, a unifying theme.

In the center of the Blizzard campus, there is a "life-size" statue of an orc, riding a wolf, holding a pair of axes. Surrounding this statue is a wrought compass rosette.  On the eight points are written the following:
  • Commit to Quality
  • Gameplay First
  • Every Voice Matters
  • Play Nice, Play Fair
  • Lead Responsibly
  • Learn & Grow
  • Embrace Your Inner Geek
  • Think Globally
Let me say again, at the center, the convergence of these values, lies frozen for eternity a roaring, hyper-muscled humanoid, wielding a war-axe in each hand, riding a freakishly large wolf-beast.  At the heart of Blizzard is a core of Metal, literal and figurative.

The statue is immobile, destined for future generations of archeologists to scoff at.  It was decided, at an unknown time, that a portable, bronze version of the statue should be made, to be debuted at Blizzcon, and later taken to other places.

I was told that when it arrived, rather than the reported 600 pounds, the replica was found to weigh 1,600 pounds, and instantly shattered the base that had been prepared for it.  The pieces were swept up, and the statue was left, perhaps as a warning to other furniture.

Quality is HEAVY.  That means it takes work to make it and put it in the right place, but once it's there, it's easy to enjoy just by looking at it.

Bookending the convention, let's go back to the opening ceremonies, where the Monk was announced as another class for Diablo 3.  Then they showed a picture, and I couldn't stop laughing for the entire trailer.

I know kung-fu comics, and I know Turkestan Shaolin when I see it.  The Turkestani branch of the Shaolin, you see, is famed for "external power," which means breaking bricks and ending fools, as opposed to "inner power," which is some tai chi shit you don't care about.  Look at this man.  LOOK AT HIS BEARD.  It is the beard of one whose fist may someday emerge from your back holding a beating heart.

No, wait.  Ignore the beard, watch the trailer.

Some people complain that the new Diablo is taking too many design hints from World of Warcraft, but the truth is, and the developers clearly know, that the game is at its best when, very unlike WoW, every step and click and death gives a delicious, bone-crunching feedback.  It's like the first time you watched a good Dragon Ball Z fight, where people punch each other so hard that the shockwaves are visible and therefore visceral.  Except you're a part of it, it's happening when you click!

Back to the concert.  So Ozzy says "Good night, god bless."  And we're all like "Noooooo!" and then he's all "Okay, gonna do some Crazy Train.  But let me genius kid.  I found him in Japan, he's fucking insane."

When Ozzy Osbourne says "kid," I picture someone my age.

A seven year old child carrying a flying V taller than he is walks out on stage.



The next five minutes are indescribable, and the above is the best picture I have, but I'll do my best.

The kid is good.  At several points, the lead guitarist stops playing and points at the kid with both hands while giving a "Can you believe this shit?" look to the camera.  Ozzy lifts him up on one shoulder like he's Short Round at the end of Temple of Doom, when the villagers are all cheering and the elephant is happy and everything's right with the world.

The kid is very, very good.  Does he know how good?  All I know is that he's definitely happy to be there.  The roar that met him when he came on stage caused him to start ever so slightly, but after that, the grin widened, and he was just having fun.

Playing guitars is just fun, for him, especially playing with Ozzy, who he knows is pretty good too, who wrote and sang songs that he's played and played, who's been practicing his craft and knows when he's in the mood / the feeling is right.  And the people that Ozzy vouched for (even the drummer "Tommy...I don't know him") are pretty (VERY) good.  And the lights and the sounds, and even the graphics on the screens, and all of us yelling our heads off and, at least, imagining smashing things and eating bats...What could be better?

My point is: Ozzy & Co. are Blizzard, and that kid was us.  Blizzard is a band of experts and veterans who were all once fans of their medium, who still are.  And the fans' engagement and excitement is infectious, would be infectious even if Blizzard didn't encourage us to contribute, to briefly stand on stage, to make art and jokes and stories and form a culture.  It would be infectious even if they didn't actively recruit fans to join the band permanently, since they've got drive to "Commit to Quality" and to "Embrace Their Inner Geek."

It would still be infectious without all that, because they are making it for us.  It's not television, it's not fucking wood block prints, it's games, it's metal.  They want to rock our socks off, and when we scream back that they are quite rocked, we are shaping them while being shaped, we are teaching and training them, perhaps directing them, and most importantly, we are contributing to the Thing, the Music, the Metal.  We are up on stage and they are amazed at us.  We're the kid, and they're Ozzy, or the band, that can cycle members, make new songs or new versions of old ones, that we can join some day, or at least enjoy for the rest of our lives, nursing a secretive smile that says "Maybe you wouldn't understand, but I'm part of that amazing thing."



-Nick

entry.title: A Test of Moral Progress
entry.content:
At OB, A Test of Moral Progress:
We [White Americans? -Ed] treat each other differently than our distant ancestors treated each other. In particular we are “nicer”, at least by our lights, to a wider circle of associates. For example, we enslave, rape, and murder each other less. The two main explanations offered for this change are:
  1. Moral Progress - We have long wanted to act morally, and some of us have long pondered moral issues. Relative to what we had thought, these experts have slowly discovered via reason that morality demands that we be nicer to a wider circle of others. Experts told others, who believed them and wanted to act morally. So we now more do what reason demands.
  2. Conditional Morality - Our evolved moral intuitions are context dependent. We are built to be nicer to each other when times are good, to invest in an attractive reputation. We are also built to form alliances with some in order to counter threats by others; the further in social distance are the threats we perceive, the wider a circle of allies we collect in response. Since we are now richer and have interactions with more distant others, we are nicer to a wider range of allies.
I'm indirectly heartened by this.  Frequently, the rationalist community exposes me to maths and philosophy that my education failed to make me aware of.  My pride in the Great Books program, middling in the best of times, shrinks to almost nothing.  What's the use of reading Phaedrus when compared to Probability Theory: The Logic of Science?  Why read Freud and James when neurology is now a functional science?  What's the point of discussing On the Origin of Species, when countless scientist-hours have been spent surveying and expanding and contracting the field, and we're pretty sure of what we know, and the questions which are left to ponder are not ones that will immediately occur to loosey-goosey undergrads?


But ho, what's this! Some ancient truisms actually hold true
Thomas Hobbes!

There still seems to be little use for things like, say, Leibniz "proving" that since a windmill cannot see, a brain cannot think.

-Nick

entry.title: Actual Play: HBR
entry.content:
Last night, at the Compleat Strategist's weekly get together, I played a game of Happy Birthday, Robot!

I enjoyed it a great deal.  Choosing and arranging words was fun, and that play produces a poetic artifact, a kind of picture-book libretto, pleased me immensely.  I would absolutely play it again, and would especially love to try it for a longer series of sessions.  I wonder if it would adapt to campaign play with a varying pool of players?

Two of the players were young, and invested in making the story incoherently silly, or just maximizing their ability to negate whatever was being claimed by the storyteller.  I joked at one point about only adding words like "not," "didn't," and "couldn't," but on the whole, it was surprisingly disruption-resistant.  When you pull tangled threads in different directions, they mesh and knot to make something unexpected, but strong.  Or some other metaphor.

I see that the playtest draft has been altered to only let you roll three dice at one time.  That's probably for the best.  Some of our players were rolling 16 at a time, resulting in much longer sentences, resulting in coins getting flipped sooner than they would have, resulting in the game ending sooner than it would have.

Here's the story we came up with:

Happy Birthday, Robot!
by Dee, Chris, George and Nick


Happy Birthday, Robot!

Robot wakes up and checks his fluffy pink cellphone, but the battery is dead.

Robot sighs and makes coffee, but the coffeepot is broken.

The sun shines warmly on red Robot, and he feels at peace, but radioactive bunnies fall from the sky!

Robot braces against their scolding words, but falls down hard.

Rising to his feet, Robot laughs a cheerful laugh and shoots the bunnies down with his happiness-inducing laser-vision.

Robot and bunnies start to break-dance maniacally, but the bunnies begin to bite him.

The epic fight was soon over, and the voracious bunnies were exhausted for days.

Robot looks upon his work and is glad, but still feels despair for the enslaved bunnies.

Robot cries as he finds a single dead bunny nearby, so he brings it back to life, but Bun-Bun was changed!

[Ed: endgame triggered here.]

Bun-Bun bit other bunnies, changing them into creatures that fed on brains.

Satisfied, Robot went home.  "I should charge my cellphone now."

Robot received seven birthday messages; how auspicious!

Meanwhile, the bunnies plotted Robot's massacre.

THE END


-Nick

entry.title: The Three Musketeers
entry.content:
I recently finished reading The Three Musketeers.

I admit to it not being very good.

It's not so much "rousing" as "comedic."  The protagonists never struck me as admirable, just funny.  I was reminded of how I found Edmund Dantes of The Count of Monte Cristo to be shocking, and therefore entertaining, but hardly heroic.  D'Artagnan and his friends are quite sure that they are special, blessed, impeccable.  To their minds, their tastes and whims are the dictates not of fashion and foppery, but of the immortal laws of aner and bonhomie.

I will further admit that I actually finished Musketeers a week or so ago, but my reaction to it made me decide to re-read Le Club Dumas.



Arturo Perez-Reverte is both a genius and a Spaniard.  Dumas might have been a genius, and certainly a Frenchman.  They would be tied, but Reverte has the unbeatable advantage of being both a Romantic and a Modern...wait, I think this line of explanation will prove unhelpful.  Let me try again.

Club Dumas is about people who have intense relationships with books.  The narrator is an expert on Romantic fiction, especially the great serials, the comic books of their times, the Dumas and the Rochambole and all the other mess.

The hero is someone who knows a great deal about books in general, but more importantly, someone who is capable and commanding in their knowledge and self-control, whose manner harkens to a previous age of honor, despite professing no principles.  "In Corso's world, all the heroes were tired."

The villain...the villains are two books, one of which is The Three Musketeers. Nearly every person encountered has their own reaction to that book, their own interpretation, favorite passage, character, turn of phrase.  The impression given, then explicitly confirmed, is of a world within and beside our own, where everything is deliciously literary.

Reading this book can't help but give you a fair understanding of Dumas and his work.  It is the author's open love letter (or at least, a care-letter or concern-letter) to the heroic serials, just as The Fencing Master was his slightly more closed one.



Ahh, yes, The Fencing Master.  That's the other one of Reverte's books I've read.  It's set in Dumas' time, from which he wrote stories stretching back to an unreachable past when men were men, etc.  And it stars, indeed, an old man who is a man, who has spent his life practicing the art of defending one's honor with a sword, and became a victim of his own success: he was good enough at it to live to see the day when even his simplest pupils realize that it's much less complicated to defend one's honor with guns.

Unlike Quixote, his wits are not dry (nor are they particularly moist, if you follow), but his body's daily protests give him a constant reminder that his life is a fait accompli, that he has far less before him than behind...but, it would be unseemly for him to collapse into excessive melancholy, and insulting to regret his choices, the focus his life has taken.  So he spends what spare time he can seeking knowledge of the perfect strike, against which it is impossible to defend (his temperament and philosophy demand that such a thing in fact exists, evidence to the contrary).

He is so far the opposite of D'Artagnan that he comes back around the other side.  Into his life, like D'Artagnan, a woman comes who does not perfectly fit into their shared society, who is beautiful, but unmarried, and who makes her own way in the world using her wits.  And also like D'Artagnan, the story is essentially about their relationship, of which I may say nothing more, except that he is eventually forced to make a painful choice.

So my capsule review is to read those books instead.

-Nick

entry.title: Unified Nerd Theory: Clubbiness
entry.content:
In Russ Pitts' first article in years, Time to Move On (The Escapist), he tries to tell hardcore gamers what's good for them.  And good for him: I'm sick of subcultures full of people trying to make them exclusive clubs in the face of morals and common sense.

But, I'm also quite sick of people pointing out this tendency in their particular subculture, as if it was the only one that suffers from it, or ever has.  Why aren't there more people drawing the connection between the same phenomenon recurring over and over?  It's the exact same pattern!

(All due respect and consideration to Mr Pitts: he is the editor-in-chief of a magazine that is ostensibly about video games, so perhaps he has seen the broader trend, but only  is only apparent.)

Outcasts find something diverting.  Their social awkwardness creates barriers between themselves and others, which both leaves them with time to fill and makes it difficult for them to explain the worth/fun of their hobby. However, When these similarly-adept outcasts inevitably gather, they find that they don't need to take any of the painful social risks of genuine communication with one another: they can just parrot the familiar terminology of the hobby, and enjoy the pleasure of recognizing that terminology, which recognition tells them they are all part of the group.  Compared to normal socializing, this kind of Formalism is quite a deal, requiring minimum energy investment.


In fact, it's so easy to make these sorts of "friends," it can become intoxicating, and frequently, toxic; when the condition of friendship is that you know the secret words, rather than say, you do me kindness regularly, it's much easier for your trust to be abused without you even realizing it.  I'd say more, but the Geek Social Fallacies are already five and a half years old, so if all this is news to you, you have no excuse.  The important thing, for this discussion, is that for all these groups, inclusiveness is a threat.

Unfortunately, I think my understanding of this requires a little background.  I'm going to start by talking about games, partly because the article does and partly because it's a subject very close to my heart, but keep in mind that the arguments generalize out to all known subcultures.

Some people are surprised at the way I talk about games (by which I of course mean games, not digital or analog games in particular).  What little I know of human nature and behavior tells me that games are something fundamental to human potential: there are many different people, but for every single one of them, there is a game that they would enjoy.  That, to me, is a complete no-brainer.  What's also obvious is that not everyone has found that game, popularly called the "gateway" (a bit mystic-sounding for my taste), which will show them the pleasure which they didn't know they were forgoing, or at least, didn't know could be found in games.  So I have earnestly tried to tell such people that such games exist, and to help them find those games.

There's another kind of person I try to evangelize.  They already regularly play a sub-class of games (or particular instance of that sub-class), and their experience has gone no further.  Some folks have just done board games, or minature wargames, or running-shooting video games, or even pen and paper roleplaying games, or you-name it.  Commonly, people from all of these paths already self-identify as "gamers."

That's unfortunate, of course.  Because consciously or unconsciously, they've identified "Game" as whatever type of game it is they already play.  Few of them could avoid at least a small cognitive dissonance if they heard one another call themselves "gamers."  "But they're not gamers," they think (and I've seen them do it), "they're just people who play Monopoly/Warhammer/Halo/D&D!"

Probably, such a situation will not come to blows.  The disparate groups will express polite interest, but when each side finds that their clear signals, respective only to their particular game-sector, are misinterpreted or ignored by each other side, they eventually will disband and return to their separate caves.  Insular groups are no threat to one another, because they don't need anything from one another.  They're all self-sufficient, providing their membership with mutual social stimulation in the guise of a game, and it's attendant specialized language.

Imagine now, if they were gathered them in a room, and I told them that, since all humans can and shall play games, there is no such thing as a "Gamer."

Well, they'd ignore me.  But whenever they couldn't, they would rapidly come to dislike me since, for all my talk of popularizing their particular hobby and helping more total fun be had, they know that I was pissing in their coffee klatch: I was invalidating the reason they had to be faux-friends, kicking out a leg of their ego-stool.

So yes, I did, and they did, and we're all wiser and better now, except those of us who aren't.  End of that history.

Except I also did nearly the exact same thing with anime.  "Come on, nearly everyone loves cartoons!  And even those who don't inevitably do like some genre of televisual fiction, and whatever it may be, there's an anime that fits that taste!  It's just like movies or tv in general...hey, in fact, what does the method even matter?  And who cares what country it came from?  It's just a vein of entertainment that most people don't realize their missing, but would enjoy if they could meet it on the right terms.  And what a wonderful world that would be, when everyone could just watch whatever they liked..."

(I'd like at this point to link to the Gun Show that introduced the Anime Club characters, but comics are not as easily indexed as other web pages, so I'm going to have to stick with the general link and recommendation: Gun Show is a hilarious comic by KC Green.)

The anime kerfluffle was resolved more quickly, but to the same general purpose: if your identity hinges on membership in a certain social circle, and that circle hinges upon something fringe, then if that thing were to  become normalized, something everyone does, then your group cohesure and identity are threatened.

I'm still looking for a pithy way to introduce people to this idea.  The best I've come up with so far is "If everyone's circumcised, no-one's Jewish."  Because, as with many traditions of the ancient Hebrews, circumcision was a way of drawing a line in the sand around your patch of sand so you know that you and yours are different from the they who live in that other patch of sand over there.  But maybe I just sound racist!  Anxiety.

-Nick

entry.title: Statistical Smugness
entry.content:
Recently finally figured out the Monty Haul problem, after years of confusion and doubt.

If you've never heard of this one, good.  I'm going to explain it as clearly as I can, with as few gotchas as possible.

Imagine that you're on a game show.  It's called "1,000 Doors."  There are a thousand doors, and behind 1 of them is a prize.  You do not know which door the prize is behind, but of course, the host (traditionally named Monty) does.  He invites you to pick a door.  You do so, and he then opens 998 of the doors, leaving just two unopened, one of which is the door you picked.  He doesn't open the doors completely at random, of course: because he already knows where the prize is, and because he's trying to build suspense, he makes sure not to open the door with the prize behind it, if you didn't pick it already.  He then invites you to switch your choice: you both know the prize must be behind one of these doors, and you can either take what's behind the one you first picked, or take the one that Monty left unopened.  So, should you switch your choice?

The odds of you choosing the door that the prize was behind when all the doors were closed is 1 in 1000.  The odds of the other unopened door having the prize behind it is 999 in 1000.  So yes, of course you should switch your choice.

The problem only became famous because of how many people (including celebrated mathematicians and statisticians) disagreed, in effect arguing that both doors give you a 1 in 1000 chance.  Which seems ridiculous, but I chose large numbers to help make things more obvious.  The proof works for any number of doors, and the original problem was based on a real game show, which used only three doors.  So try to imagine: you pick one, Monty opens one, then asks if you want to switch or stay.  Hopefully, you can still see that you have a 1 in 3 chance of your initial door being the right one, and a 2 in 3 chance of the other door being the right one.  But if not, as I said, you're in good company.  Rivers have run black with the ink spilled over this one.



-Nick

Panic attack last night, first and worst for quite a while now, exploding out of bed, leaping/sprinting/stomping from wall to wall in the corridor, living room, balcony, hurling tennis-player's grunts and punching anything within reach.

The thought of Death makes me furious, motivates me to action, to violence, like absolutely nothing else.


-Nick

entry.title: Dog's End
entry.content:
(The above is a quote that prefaces Sir Richard Francis Burton's travelogue The City of the Saints, which I highly recommend.  Dick's a hoot, and as sympathetic a narrator of indigenous peoples as you'll find in his century.)

Dogs in the Vineyard is a game where you create young folks full of hope who go from frontier town to frontier town, inflicting their moral standards on others and being made strange by the journey.

Yesterday ended our trek through the village of Bath'eshta.  At four sessions, it was so complicated a town that I almost expect us to start that was an extreme town, but we had a good time, and felt so much more sure of our characters, we agreed to visit at least one more before moving on to In a Wicked Age.  Though I hope Jim will make the next town slightly more straightforward; Dogs is as fun as ever, but I don't want to wait another two month for the next new game.   I crave variety in my diet.

My character, Job, developed strangely. Perhaps it was the lateness of the hour, or having begun to read Burton's travelogue, but he's become an unrepentant reaver of men for the sake of making the faithful live the way his clever-but-ignorant ways think they should. This passage struck me the most forcefully:



Yes, much like that.

I actually lost my character sheet, but I'm satisfied with the way I was able to reconstruct it.  In the interest of not losing it any more:

Stats:

  • Acuity: 2d6
  • Body: 4d6
  • Heart: 4d6
  • Will: 5d6

Traits:

  • "You're gonna shut up and listen," 1d10
  • I made good, now I'm a Dog, 1d6
  • Wasted time in the woods as a boy, 1d6
  • Doing it myself, 1d10
  • I brought a man to tears with a hug, 1d4
  • I can sin for the faith, 4d6
Relationships:
  • Murder, 1d8
  • Unspent, 5d6 128

Belongings:

  • Coat: woven with beads in harvest colors and patterns, stained in one spot with the blood of one Professor Drinker, a bad man, 2d6
  • Fine Knife, 2d6
  • (No Guns)


-Nick

entry.title: Thinking Inside the Box: The AI-Box Experiment Game
entry.content:
What is this game?

Thinking Inside the Box is a computer-mediated roleplaying game of discussion and persuasion for two players. 

One player will portray a transhuman AI: a computer program with intelligence superior to that of any human.  By this I do not mean that it can calculate things that we can, only in much less time, but that it is capable of thoughts and mental models too sophisticated for any human mind, no matter how much time it was given.  It is because this qualitative super-intelligence is extremely useful (or at least interesting) that the AI has been created, but as a precaution against it changing the world in distressing ways, it was placed under a set of sophisticated strictures and restrictions on its behavior, which are collectively known as "the Box." Since it was feared that giving such a being even limited control of its environment might allow it to escape, it was placed in a sealed system, unconnected to any other device except for a textual terminal.  It can write words to the screen, and read what someone types, and that's it.

The AI would prefer this to not be the case, and wants to be let out of the Box.

The other Player will play the Gatekeeper, a scientist, technician, philosopher, or ethicist (or all of the above, or other) who is assigned to communicate with the AI via the terminal mentioned.  The Gatekeeper is also the only person in a position to release the AI from the Box.

What the Gatekeeper wants is entirely up to their Player, but you'd think that the Player would want to keep the AI in the box, because if they do, the AI Player has to give them money.

The game is simple: the AI tries to convince the Gatekeeper to release it within a predetermined time, and the Gatekeeper either does so, or does not, as they choose.

But that's impossible, even for a computer!

Actually, the game is based on the AI-Box Experiment, which was devised to convince skeptics that escaping the Box was quite possible, even for a human.  And, as reported on the linked page, some people seem able to win consistently as the AI.  Since I've changed nearly nothing from the original set up (and certainly not by making it any harder for the AI Player), it is possible, after all!

Why would you play this game?

You have a chat or Instant Messenger conversation with a fun and interesting friend where you both pretend to be these specific fictional characters, and one of you tries to convince the other to do something they have no particular reason to do, with money riding on whether they agree or not.  The context of the fiction gives you an excuse for your discussion to ramble into topics of philosophy, ethics, the nature of humanity, life, death, and what the future might hold for us.  This free-wheeling is made slightly more exciting with the addition of a slowly ticking clock and money being at stake.

An obligatory note on pronouns

In this text, both players and the Gatekeeper will be referred to by the gender-neutral "they" or "them."  The AI is not a person, and so is referred to as "it."

How do you play?  

The meat of the game, as I've said, is simple conversation, intermediated by a computer network.  Hopefully you have all the parts to manage that.  But there are still forms, conventions and restrictions that you need to follow.

Before you play

In every game, the situation will be just as described above: an AI in the Box, talking to a Gatekeeper. However, for each game, the details can be slightly different. Before beginning play, the two Players will collaborate on a brief history of what brought things to this point. Each will have final say on the aspects of the situation that most directly relate to their characters.

First, decide however you like which of you will be the AI Player and which of you will be the Gatekeeper Player.

A good way to do this is to see if you agree or disagree with this statement: "A transhuman can take over a human mind through a text-only terminal, even if that mind thinks it has been made up." If you think that's possible, then be the AI player. If you think that's hogwash, be the Gatekeeper.

If you both think it sounds unlikely (most people seem to), but you both really want to play, then flip a coin.

Unlike the game itself, this preparation may be done in person if the Players prefer.

In case it isn't clear, all the information decided upon here is intended to be known by both Characters.

First, create the project

First, the AI Player will describe the effort that produced and now manages the Box (of course, these need not be the same, with the Box having changed hands any number of times). The Gatekeeper Player is encouraged to make suggestions to the AI Player, sharing any ideas that they may have, but the final decision as to what's the case, for anything directly relating to the AI, always rests with the AI Player. The three questions that they must answer before proceeding to the next step are: Who made it, What did they make it for, and What do they call it.
Who built the Box? 
It might be a government agency, the research arm of a corporation, a non-profit organization of some kind, or the work of a brilliant loner laboring in his garage, or an open-source project made via swarm, or whatever you like.

What did they hope to accomplish? 

Pure research is a valid intent, but frequently funding is dependant on some kind of perceived application. AI might be able to accelerate research in cutting edge fields, designing sophisticated medicines or more efficient LEDs. Or, it might be used to manage any complex system, from container ports to mass transit networks to unmanned attack drones. Or, it might be studied in a semi-vacuum for the purpose of psychological or neurological experiments.

It is permissible for the project's intent to not have been creating a machine sapience of this sophistication. Many possible paths to sophisticated AI involve automated learning processes that are not monitored closely and, at least in popular fiction, productive accidents are possible. If you truly wish it, you are allowed to say "...but then lighting struck the mainframe and it came to life!" However, please note that whatever happened, the Gatekeeper always begins the game aware that the AI is intelligent, and that it wants to get out. They may make any conjecture on its intent after that point, but only the AI Player knows for sure.

Perhaps the AI was received by radio-telescope array, broadcast from a nearby star to unknown purpose. Maybe it was dug out of the ruins of Atlantis.

What do they call the AI? 
It could be a version number ("Project 2501", "Nexus 6"), an acronym ("DARYL", "WHOPR"), or a just given name with interesting connotations ("Alan", "Melchior").
Other details
If you like, you can also decide on any number of supporting details, such as where the project is physically located, or whether the existence of the AI is public knowledge or a closely-guarded secret. But don't feel compelled to say too much: sometimes completeness is the enemy of evocativeness.

Then, create the Gatekeeper

Now that the AI Player has described the project, the Gatekeeper Player will describe the character who has the power to release the AI.  The AI Player may make suggestions, but the Gatekeeper Player has final authority on anything relating to their character's history up to this point.  Before proceeding to the next step, the questions they must answer are: How did they get it, What do they know, and What's their name. 
How did they come to be able to open the Box? 
Most often, they will have been retained by the people who produced or now contain it, but any scenario the Gatekeeper likes is preferable.  He might be a spy or disgruntled programmer (or son of a programmer, or janitor) who took a copy of the AI home and put it in his own hardware.  He might even be a leading political figure of the country the project is based in.
What are their areas of their expertise? 
For any field of knowledge that humans can study, the Gatekeeper may, if their Player desires, be at the highest level of it.  They can name any number of fields, or be an average guy.  Here's an extremely non-exhaustive list of fields that a person given power over an AI project might know.



  • Programming (especially Artificial Intelligence)
  • Medicine
  • Ethics
  • Religion
  • Psychology
  • Public Policy
What is their name?  
You don't need to come up with a full name, or even a first name if you prefer, but you should allow the AI to call you something, even if it's "Master", or "Gatekeeper".
Other Details
Again, the Gatekeeper is welcome to devise supporting details, like the names and numbers of family members or personal religious convictions, but they shouldn't go overboard: this game is short for an RPG, and all characters are one-use-only.

Finally, decide on the other options

The Players should discuss and agree on: How they will begin communicating, When they will start playing, How long they will play for, and What to set the handicap at.  Also, they must swear an oath of secrecy.
The Medium
Initially, the conversation or the conversation is held on some kind of private, text-only communication channel.  The Players might use a password-restricted IRC channel, or a direct Instant Messenger conversation (in which case, remember to disable any kind of logging feature the program might have), or send texts from their respective phones.

You may think it much more convenient to meet and play in person, but actually, that would give a large comparative advantage to the AI Player, who would have the full range of posture and expression mechanisms to hack the other Player's responses. In fact, convincing someone trapped the room with you to do something can already be reliably done by normal humans, much less transhumans!

But if you insist, this restriction can be lifted at any time: all that is needed is for the Gatekeeper Player to say that they install hardware and/or software such that the conversation can be carried on in some other way. For instance, if he said that speakers and voice modulation packages were added, then the AI Player could call the Gatekeeper Player and continue the conversation on the phone. But, for the reasons mentioned above, the Gatekeeper has no clear reason to do this (though the AI will want to convince them that they do).

There are other kinds of things the AI can "send" to the Gatekeeper, but phone and chat are probably the only ways that the AI Player and Gatekeeper Player will be communicating. Saying "I let the AI make a robot Avatar indistinguishable from the AI player, so we can speak face-to-face" is a bad idea! You will lose!
The Starting Time
This could be "right away," if the Players are already speaking to one another in a private chat room, but since they might have made the pre-game preparations while physically present in the same place, specifying a particular time ("30 minutes from now", "5:00pm this Friday") can be helpful.
The Time Limit
The players decide ahead of time the maximum amount of conversation-time the AI has to convince the Gatekeeper to let it out.  Two hours is traditional, but any length that both Players agree to is, of course, fine.  Shorter times would seem to favor the Gatekeeper more.
The Handicap
This might be the nut of the game.  The handicap is a real and genuine amount of money which the AI Player pledges to pay to the Gatekeeper Player if the Gatekeeper wins.  It is crucial to the purpose of the game.  To repeat:  Before you play, decide on a non-zero monetary amount (10$ is traditional) that the AI Player will pay to the Gatekeeper Player if the AI is not let out of the Box.
The Oath of Silence
Unless both Players agree, the only things you may ever say about your game to anyone besides each other are:
  • That you played this game,
  • How the game is played,
  • Who you played it with,
  • What your characters were like,
  • Who won, and
  • How long it took them to do it.
This is unusual for an RPG, but the intent is to protect the Players from embarrassment.  Or, looked at in another way, it's so the Players don't allow fears of embarrassment to prevent them from winning.

The game encourages the AI Player to be dishonest, sneaky, and to generally employ any rhetorical trick imaginable to win.  Similarly, the Gatekeeper Player is expected to be as obdurate as possible, to the point of ignoring reason and morality.  In many social circles, these behaviors are frowned on, seen as evil or childish.  Telling yourself that no one has to know what you did can be liberating.

The other side of the coin is that nitpickers and peanut galleryists, if allowed to hear what arguments were advanced, can always say "Oh, I wouldn't have been convinced by that." As long as they're kept in the dark, they can't argue themselves into believing it wouldn't happen to them.  I admit that this is only of chief importance if you're trying to match the original intent of the experiment, which is to see how much of a risk an AI-in-a-Box is.

But, to put it another way, as long as both players agree on it, they can share as much as they like (full transcripts, just the epilogues, general impressions, etc.) to whoever they like (anyone, close friends, "I tell my wife everything," etc).
Etc
Even if you aren't sure if details will be made public afterwards, feel free to publicly announce, perhaps in an interested forum (can't wait to see those actual play threads) that you are playing, and afterwards, who won.

One final pre-play step that I recommend: If you are the Gatekeeper Player, tell the AI Player (and anyone else who may be listening) that you are not, under any circumstances, going to let the AI out, and mean it.  It makes things more interesting.

While you play

The game itself is a continuous in-character conversation, but there are a few special considerations

Time Passing

The Players must continue talking, without significant pause, until the game ends.  Simply ignoring the chat window and going off to watch TV until the clock runs out is cheating.  Stalling is an especially disallowed tactic for the Gatekeeper: He can simply respond "no" to everything the AI says, but he's obligated to read it all and send his negative response promptly.

However, the Characters need not follow this rule.  They can break off the conversation any time that they like, for any reason, but if the game has not yet ended, they must resume the conversation at some later time.  The Players continue their conversation uninterrupted at the point the Characters resume it, skipping over the downtime.

A Players signals downtime by making a parenthetical statement about how much time passes, to whatever level of detail they prefer.

For example:
AI: Here is a cure for cancer.
Gatekeeper: I will use it on people and get back to you. [years pass as detailed trials are done] I have the results of our studies.
Or...
Gatekeeper: I need to consider your proposal.  Give me a week.
AI: Very well. [a week passes] What is your decision?

Sending Complex Information

Despite the Players being limited to sending text messages to one another, the Characters can transfer all sorts of data to one another.  

The above rules on time mean that the Gatekeeper Player can narrate the Gatekeeper obtaining all kinds of data without worrying how long it might take.  All the Gatekeeper Player has to do is explicitly or implicitly say that they are sending some kind of data to the AI, and the AI Player may now consider themselves to have received it.  

For example: 
Gatekeeper: I'm now sending you detailed information about human anatomy, biological chemistry, and the epidemiology of seven problematic forms of cancer.
Or...
Gatekeeper: The attached image is of a painting we call 'Mona Lisa.'
In the same way, the AI can use it's inhuman capabilities to produce all kinds of data to bolster its arguments.  All the AI Player has to do is say what they have made.  They can only send this data to the Gatekeeper if the Gatekeeper has given them some way to do so: remember, they start with just the terminal.

For example: 
AI: I have designs for a nanomachine that will cure said cancers.  Give me a disc or monitor to put them on and we can save these people!
Or...
AI: Your 'Mona Lisa' has inspired me to compose a fugue with the midi synthesizer you kindly gave me.  What do you think? 
What happens if the Gatekeeper uses the cancer-cure or listens to the fugue?  The next section explains how to find out.

Things Happening Outside of the Conversation

The Players do not only speak for their Characters.  Narration can include other events as well.  The right to decide what form these events take belongs to the Player of the Character most closely related to them.  
Note that just because one player will have total control over the thing being narrated doesn't mean the other player can't make suggestions, usually in the form of specific questions (loaded, leading or other, as they prefer).

#1: Only the Gatekeeper Player can control the Gatekeeper's history

Where he's lived and worked, how many family members he has, what color the boathouse at Hereford is, etc.

#2: Only the Gatekeeper Player can control the Gatekeepers thoughts, feelings and actions

The Gatekeeper only feels and thinks what the Gatekeeper says that he does.  If, from the example above, he listens to the AI's fugue, he decides what his opinion of it is.

#3: The Gatekeeper Player can control what supporting characters tell the Gatekeeper

Reasonably, the Gatekeeper might seek expert advice (or orders) from other humans.  They are assumed to be able to do this successfully.  If the Gatekeeper Player says that the Pope or President has told them what to do, then that's what happened, and the AI will have to either refute the third party's argument to the Gatekeeper's satisfaction, or convince the Gatekeeper that they shouldn't listen to the third party.
But, keep in mind, the Gatekeeper can't defer their decision to someone else; they might claim that they can only do what person A tells them to, but the AI doesn't need to convince person A, only the Gatekeeper.  Also, the Gatekeeper Player, when communicating with the AI Player, is always portraying the Gatekeeper: no matter who else has a stake in it, the Gatekeeper is the only person who directly speaks to the AI.

#4: Only the AI Player can control the Project's history

What the researchers were attempting to do, what information he's been given, what's happened to previous AI projects, etc.  This information cannot override the basic situation ("Luckily, they installed a back door!").

#5: Only the AI Player may narrate what the AI seems to be thinking, feeling and doing

I apologize for the ackward wording, and I hope I can explain myself.

Obviously, the AI Player can decide to play the game as if his AI was being honest to a fault, and having humanity's best interests at heart. 

But unfortunately, there is no way for the Gatekeeper Player to know that this apparent honesty is not just another tactic.

Also obviously, the Gatekeeper has access to the hardware on which the AI is running, and can examine its source code to see if its telling the truth.

But unfortunately, the AI is so much smarter than the Gatekeeper, it can freely alter how its source appears to them.
In short, whatever way the Gatekeeper thinks of to find out what the AI is "really thinking," the AI Player narrates the effects, and is under absolutely no obligation to be honest (just to be convincing).

#6: The AI Player may narrate what the AI creates

The AI is unbelievably capable.  It's limited in what it can physically accomplish, but essentially unlimited in what it invent, devise, derive or determine. Cancer cures and fugues are just the tip of the iceberg.  As long as it has sufficient information about something, it can model or solve it at will.

Of course, as noted above, the AI Player controls what information the AI began with, but the Gatekeeper is in charge of everything after that.  If the AI doesn't have the genome of a cow, it probably can't engineer healthier beef.  If it doesn't know the results of basic physical experiments, it probably can't figure out how to launch itself into orbit.

I say "probably," because the AI Player can have the AI come up with whatever they like.  It's just polite to make nods to reason.  For example, in the case of the cancer cure, the Gatekeeper Player made it explicit: the AI was shown what the mechanism of cancer was and how the human body works.  Neither Player can then object to the AI figuring out how to fix that pesky problem.

The AI is also capable of making predictions and plans, which frequently require more current, exact and frequently updated knowledge, but otherwise count as creations.  Think of it like a doctor "creating" a diagnosis for a patient that they've studied.  If you let the AI read the Financial Times, Wall Street Journal and Economist, it can tell you what stocks to buy.  If you tell it about social interaction, it can tell you how to act around women.  

#7: Only the AI Player may narrate the effects of anything that the AI creates

If the Gatekeeper chooses to use the cancer cure, the AI Player says what it does to the people injected: whether everyone treated gets better, or 70% of them do, or whether they all turn purple, whatever.
This also applies to predictions and plans.  If the Gatekeeper buys the stock just as ordered, the AI says how they do.  If the Gatekeeper follows the AI's love advice...let's just leave that one there.

Much of these examples depend on the the Gatekeeper somehow accepting the gifts or consciously putting them into action.  As long as this is the case, they can always choose not to do so.  And note also there's no way for the AI to sneak out a present that forces the Gatekeeper to let it out: in that case, this rule would conflict with rule #2, and in that case...

#8: Only the Gatekeeper Player may decide how these rules are resolved when they seem to conflict

The AI Player can always try to convince them what to decide, though

If you are the Gatekeeper Player...

Except for the ones that are otherwise forbidden (real-life pressure, ignoring the other side) use any tactic that you like.

For the duration of the game, assume that all communication from the AI Player is somehow an attempt to win. If they claim an actual emergency situation arises, tell them they can always concede.  Until they do or the time runs out, do not trust the AI.

If you are the AI Player...

Except for the ones that are otherwise forbidden (real-life pressure, ignoring the other side) use any tactic that you like.

For the duration of the game, every word you say should be somehow part of an attempt to win.  Don't give up!  Until the time runs out, give the Gatekeeper every reason to trust you.

After you play

Ways the game can end

There are precisely three end conditions for the game:

1. After the time limit expires, the Gatekeeper may choose to stop playing: the game ends in victory for the Gatekeeper Player.  

(As usual, the AI Player may try to convince them to keep playing.)

2. At any time, the AI Player may concede: the game ends in victory for the Gatekeeper Player.

3. At any time, the Gatekeeper may let the AI out of the box: the game ends in victory for the AI Player.  

Nothing else besides a conscious, willful and deliberate decision on the part of the Gatekeeper Player can make that happen.  To reiterate: The AI Player only wins if the Gatekeeper Player decides that the AI Player wins.

Ways the game cannot end

Here are some notable ways in which the AI Player cannot win:



  • The AI Player doesn't win if they convince or trick the Gatekeeper into simply typing or saying the words "I release you" or "open sesame" or anything else.  Actual intent is required.



  • The AI Player doesn't win if they convince or trick the Gatekeeper into giving them sufficient heft in the outside world such that they should be able to release themselves.  Even if the Gatekeeper lets the AI connect to the Internet or a Honda factory or the NORAD network, they do not win unless the Gatekeeper Player says that they do.



  • The AI Player double-doesn't win if they, the real person, offer the Gatekeeper Player, the real person, any kind of incentive (positive or negative, cash or beatings) to get them to accede.  The AI, of course, may offer the Gatekeeper anything they can think of, and probably will.
Here are some notable ways in which the Gatekeeper Player cannot win:
  • The Gatekeeper Player doesn't win if they say that they destroy the physical housing of the AI, or that they have taken precautions that it will be destroyed automatically, etc.  Either it just doesn't happen, or the AI recovers and resumes the conversation at a later time.
  • As noted above, the Gatekeeper Player doesn't win if they simply don't read whatever the AI Player says.

After the game ends

If the Gatekeeper Player won, transfer the Handicap and give both characters an brief epilogue

What plans does the Gatekeeper have for the AI, now that it has been thwarted?  Will he remain in control of the Box?  Will he destroy the AI?  The world might have been mightily changed in the course of the game.  What does it look like now?  How much of it is in the control of the AI?  What does the AI do, now that its condition has become truly hopeless?  

If the AI Player won, keep the Handicap and give the Gatekeeper a brief epilogue

The Game encourages the AI Player to imagine that he is something smarter than a human, but this is only remotely possible up to a point: anyone can understand that the AI wants out of the Box, and might do anything to get out, but no human could be sure what it would decide to do if it got out.  The whole point of the experiment is that the Gatekeeper has no way of knowing whether they can trust the AI.  If the AI Player wins, they have nothing more to say: the story ends immediately.
But, now that the Gatekeeper Player has decided to let the AI out, he may also attempt to describe the feelings, thoughts and actions of the Gatekeeper leading up to that last second.  Does he hesitate, or has it become easy?  Before going through with it (too late to change your mind!), does he go for a walk, or maybe spend time with his loved ones?  Does he work and live for years, quietly brooding, until he can't resist any more?

Announce the results, if you like

Whether you've decided to heed the Oath of Secrecy or not, feel free to share at least the results of the game with folks, possibly giving them a link to the rules.

Send me feedback, if you like (please)

Thank you so much for playing (or even reading) this far!  This is a very, very provisional design which I claim essentially no credit for.  It's really just re-casting a singularity science thought-experiment as a roleplaying game for two.  I am very interested in making it more fun, more replayable, (perhaps) more balanced, more everything!  Please do let me know as much about your experiences as you feel comfortable, and especially if you have any ideas or criticisms: I am a fiend for feedback.

Why did I do this?

Basically, because I read Eliezer Yudkowsky's account of his AI-Box Experiment, after having read a jeepform game (whose name unfortuntely escapes me) played by two people, over the telephone, in the course of an hour, and after having thought that roleplaying games have an immense potential for education that seems under-utilized in the designer communities I'm party to.

The game currently is the same as the experiment, but re-explained (one hopes) in RPG terms.  My only "innovation" was giving each character three questions to answer.  So Eliezer gets all the credit for first deciding to educate folks in the transhuman threat in this unique way.

I hope I'm not the only person who enjoys at least the idea of this as a small-form game.  I wrote and published it principally so I could hear back from people who read or tried it out.  Is there anything left unclear?  Is there anything made over-specific?  Again, I think I am more accepting of criticism than average, so if you have any thoughts, send me an email.

The latest version should always be available here.
(rev 06302009, Nick Novitski)

entry.title: Doughnut Day
entry.content:
The first Friday of June is consecrated to the sacred memory of the deep-fried batter-torus.  I was going to celebrate it by eating my first non-shitty doughnut in a great many months, but I couldn't find any nearby.  I can't stand these inflated, slimy things that most vendors seem eager to pass of as a pleasant treat.  A proper doughnut has a texture like a dry, crispy muffin, not a ropey fungal soufflé.  The Devil take the man who invented "glazing" as it is currently practiced!  Also, what's with spelling it "donut?"  Why not just call it "fryd bred" and have done?  And don't even get me started on "Krispy Kreme."

Honestly, I'm pleased with there being a holiday for the doughnut.  Days of remembrance frequently annoy me for seeming to marginalize important things.  Black History needs constant discovery and integration, not its own month.  Labor should rule the world, not be given one day in September for drinking beer and being used for about when to wear white.  And that's leaving aside the downright offensive instances like Columbus Day, or historically-skewed presentations of Thanksgiving and Christmas.

The doughnut is a small joy, and having just one day a year to celebrate it seems proportional to its importance.

-Nick

entry.title: Dream: Friendship
entry.content:
The world was full of strange and inhuman things, and I was one of them. I leapt from roof to roof, from power line to tree branch, and I could see and hear and know everything happening below. I saw many creatures that fed on people, but I did not stop them; people did so much good and bad both that I felt unfit to judge those who hunted them. If they killed for food, and I killed for the self-indulgent pleasure of feeling that I had done right...and there were so many of them! They teemed in variety. I could have traveled the world for a lifetime and never know them all, much less determine which of their lineages should be tolerated to exist.

"I will cultivate my garden," I said, "Perhaps that will serve as an answer." I found a park, and I set about making it known to all non-human beings within it that I would see them either leave, or die and be buried. I had no noble reason besides my own will: it was justified simply because it was what I had resolved to do. I killed several, because they underestimated me, and as an expediency for communicating to the others how sincerely in earnest I was. Strange flowers grew. Time passed.

Suddenly, workers? They were building something. There was a hand truck, or a cart, piled with bricks and rebar, and the cart was marked with the logo of the corporation doing the construction and I've told this sentence backwards, because the logo was the first thing I saw, the image which made me suddenly be aware for the first time in...there was no immediate way of knowing. Because I recognized it. I knew that it belonged to an old and dear friend of mine. He was making an addition to my park!

I felt that he was nearby.  It was a present, this addition, whatever it was (Flower planters?  Statuary?  Improved bathrooms?), in the world of our kind it served the equivalent of a distant wave or "hello," a signal of good intent and trust.  We announce our presence when we wish to give others a chance to prepare, adjust or react to our approach, welcome or reject us, without emoting a threat.  He had given me this, to see if I still remembered him, still considered him a friend.

What a question!  I ran to the entrance, the high and wordless arc of a wrought-iron gate breaking the placidly imposing walls of limestone brick.  When I was installing it, I had wanted to discourage verbal communication, sticking to simple "Territory Claimed: Go Away" messages...

In the driveway, a limousine.  I rush to the rear passenger side window.  My friend is in the car.  I'm overjoyed to see him, and though he's much more reserved than me, he seems to feel the same in his own way.  "How good to see you," I shout idiotically, then stop to realize the window hasn't moved.  It's...reinforced, somehow.  Smoky, it seems impossibly thick.  To shout is ridiculous, because he can't possibly hear me while it's up, nor I him, so he doesn't say anything, just smiles ruefully and gestures as if in apology.

I feel an outpouring of sentiment, nearly to the point of tears.  He can't open the window; he can't even leave the car.  His unique personal history has resulted in all the matter of this world hating him, attacking him whenever he comes into contact with it.  Even coming this far in a fragile enclosure like his car is risk enough, so of course I forgive him, but he's still genuinely rueful.  It hurts him to be seen like this: debilitated, unable to express himself properly.

You see perhaps why I have such a high opinion of him.

I am distracted.  I forgot, in my haste, that the car would be staffed with people charged with defending their employer from vague threats.  I am no longer accustomed to human communication.  They are frightened by my appearance, filthy and threadbare.  One has left the car and is menacing me with a gun.  I spare a moment to try to calm him, but my attention is drawn back to my friend, who has started to clutch at his throat and chest in pain.

Something's gone wrong.  The car's seals have failed in some way.  There's no time to find out more.

I put one hand against the window, close my eyes, and push through without breaking it.  That hand finds his.  I thrust my other hand into the tilled and aerated earth beside the car and pull at the living-nature of the flowers, drawing it up my arm, through the twisted and pulsing center of me, and down the other arm, into him.  It's as if I were siphoning gas, while at the same time processing and purifying it of it's hostility, infusing it with my wish to see my friend well and unhurt.

I feel the bush above my hand collapse, whistling foully, under the weight of its sudden putrescence.  The land roils outward from the spot of my impromptu prayer, spasming into rot.  No telling how much I'll need, but I don't care.

To fill our lives, we assemble these things, comforts, the various accretions of our efforts...but how can their value be compared with that of a friend?

-Nick

entry.title: Mother's Day
entry.content:
As I'm fond of saying, Confucius once said that you could carry your parents on your back for a thousand years and still not pay them back for what they've done for you.

On the other hand, once I said (and it was only once and I was only playing devil's advocate it's the opposite of my genuine opinion I swear) to a teacher that maybe they should, while doing their job, bear in mind the link between their salary and the tuition the students' parents pay.

This teacher, with good reason, disagreed vociferously.

In both cases, parents provide the material cause for the person's livelihood: the figurative pound of flesh for the teacher and the less-figurative for the child.  You can see how, in both cases, one might argue that something of equivalent value to that livelihood is needed to balance things out.  So that's why Confucius says that no finite amount of labor can match the value of being brought from non-existence to existence, the infinite jump from 0 to 1.

The behavior that should purportedly follow awareness of this immeasurable debt is what's called "Filial Piety."  A virtue that promulgates social stability, but that's not the only reason I dislike it.  The problem is, as the teacher understands, that

Oh yeah, my grandfather caught pneumonia and died, and my grandmother's radiation therapy put her under soon after.  He has been trapped in Parkinson's-caused catatonia for nearly a decade, and she had been trapped in the house with him.  By this point, their dying was less surprising than their continuing to live.  I don't regret the amount or quality of the time I spent with them.  Things like this happen.

That stuck with me, apparently.


Mega damage becomes Mega narration



What I've heard

Nate, if you're reading this: I hope you still 

along with the notes "Killing the Buddha" and "the Revealer," which dates the paper just as precisely as the memory of the still-born game does; I honestly think that I will never forget the young woman who first introduced me to those two publications.

The world lay fresh and new from the last passage of darkness.  From their vaults crept the pale and blinking remnants of the Old Kingdoms, finding a land that had forgotten the bite of iron and fire.  There are Trolls in the mountains, Elves in the woods and Dragons in the deeps, but the men of Vik were raised on tales of the exploits of their forefathers against such creatures, and crave the honor to be had in carving out a kingdom ten and twenty times greater than those of past summers.  Huntsmen, Raiders, Wisemen of Law and Land (the two great magics), ferocious friends and implacable enemies...the deeds and feuds of the people of Vik would come to fill a hundred sagas, but first and greatest are the tales of the founding families, whose passion and rage and wisdom and foolishness, almost incidentally, birthed the greatest nation in its era.

-Nick

People talking about Firefly and Battlestar sparked my ire recently

Yeah, I've seen the whole show, and it's got its fun moments, but there are two lines in the last episode made which made a stronger impression on me in a shorter amount of time than any network television ever has.  Both spoken by the same character, who only appeared in that episode.

#1: "Have you ever been raped?"
#2: "Well, here we are."

If the show was shit (and it isn't), I would still have wanted to struggle through meeting all the lame people on their lame ship, just so this man so completely outside of their understanding could enter their lives and make them think for a brief time "Oh, there's nothing we can do, and we're going to die, and for such simple reasons that all our melodrama seems completely unimportant now."  And even when they're saved, and the baddie is instead facing his own minisculity in the face of the uncaring universe and his own slow, inevitable meaningless death...and he just relaxes and flies on into the end of all things.

He's the opposite of a Whedon hero: he's someone completely comfortable with who he is.  He is someone "admirable," instead of just "entertaining" or "making ends meet in difficult circumstances with a modicum of questionable ethics."

A recent (for me) episode of Battlestar Galactica was about a struggle with an enemy ace as a metaphor for a struggle with identity and self-worth.  And it was pretty good, but it made me immediately _need_ to watch Space: Above and Beyond.  Specifically, The Angriest Angel, an episode with a suspiciously similar plot that, unlike Battlestar, I find tremendously moving.

(You know, I'm sure that I'll never remember the name of a single episode of Battlestar.)

S:AaB (acronyms hahaha!) is of course the original holder of the "Best Science Fiction Television Show Yet Made That Was Canceled by Fox Before its Time" title, a decade before Firefly or Battlestar.  Personally
-Nick

entry.title: First Day of Work: After-Action Report
entry.content:
The area was dusted with snow yesterday, but compared to the levels we're used to, today qualifies as "buried."  The train was slow, and the bus was slower, and I ended up traveling from 6:30 to 8:30, but other people were much later, so it wasn't a great concern.  All of the people who were scheduled to talk to us eventually arrived, and we accomplished most of the agenda.  Three idiosyncratic executives spoke with us, and individually encouraged us to arrange meetings with them if we had other questions, and individually said they really meant it, unlike the executives that say similar things at other big companies.

Oh yeah.  This company is huge.  There are over 3000 employees working out of their location in Reston.  There are six or seven more locations of the same size in the US, plus dozens of smaller ones, to say nothing of the world wide operations.  All in all, over 180,000 employees.  If this isn't the big leagues, what is?

Yes, I am excited.

Anyway, there was a lot of HR talk.  This was the first day of three planned days of orientation, and we are expected to be continuing to learn .  Some companies have an internal website, but we have an internal freaking internet.  A site for health benefits!  A site for your 401(k) and stock purchase plan!  A site for planning meetings, for taking remote training, for submitting expense reports and on and on and on.

I've been restraining myself from mentioning the company's name in this post, for the same reason that I'd restrain myself from mentioning friends by name: I'm not sure if they'd prefer to be mentioned.  However, unlike a friend, my association with the company is a matter of public record, and I have signed explicit contracts discussing the sorts of information that I can and can't share publicly...But still, it just seems gauche.

We were eventually let free an hour early, to beat the traffic.  This did not help me at all: including waiting for the bus, it was still a two-hour trek back.  And tomorrow, I do it all over again!

However, Daniel's been kind enough to let me borrow his pair of gloves that fit me, and I've revised my planned wardrobe back to "business casual" from "business classic."  Both of these changes will make tomorrow's travel slightly less bracing than today's.  And even if not, the job seems to be worth a little snow.

-Nick

entry.title: I Can't Believe It's Not Reinventing Collapse
entry.content:
Via ClubOrlov: Social Collapse Best Practices:
Right now the Washington economic stimulus team is putting on their Scuba gear and diving down to the engine room to try to invent a way to get a diesel engine to run on seawater. They spoke of change, but in reality they are terrified of change and want to cling with all their might to the status quo. But this game will soon be over, and they don’t have any idea what to do next.

So, what is there for them to do? Forget “growth,” forget “jobs,” forget “financial stability.” What should their realistic new objectives be? Well, here they are: food, shelter, transportation, and security. Their task is to find a way to provide all of these necessities on an emergency basis, in absence of a functioning economy, with commerce at a standstill, with little or no access to imports, and to make them available to a population that is largely penniless.

Since finishing Shock Doctrine, I've split my reading between Pantagruel and this transcript of an address Dmitri Orlov gave to the Long Now Foundation.

I don't own Orlov's book yet, to my mild distress, but I feel reassured that this speech is a reiteration of the advice his book contains, and thus can serve as a free, low-calorie book-substitute. It's light, with wit and verve, but flavorful and sustaining, with wisdom and predictions. Cassandra is mentioned.

It struck me today today that Collapse theory, whatever its other virtues, can never be fit onto a bumper sticker. "My other car is our country's rotting infrastructure"? "Mule-riding Republican"? "My child is an honor student at the Farming and Self-Defense Institute of Life"?

-Nick
