entry.title: Value Enhancement and Many-to-Many Relationships in Google App Engine
entry.content:
Get Rich Slowly, a financial advice column I follow, recently linked to this Newsweek article about how luck is less a matter of luck than we think.  The findings accord  fairly well with my limited observation: some people seem to flounder even in the face of what seem to me to be extremely mild "disasters," while others immediately recover and begin taking positive steps towards fixing the problem.

I don't mean to harp on the former group; I myself suffer from bouts of uselessness, anxiety, lassitude and depression, so I know how crippling those feelings can be.  But I have noticed that, on rare occasion, I've been able to shake off the shock and make progress as if I wasn't suffering, just by actively thinking that I shouldn't let whatever-it-is stop me.

Guilt is a powerful motivator for me, and when I think on those times in the past when I've let something get me down and mired in inaction, I feel the guilt keenly.  In order to prevent that as much as I can, I try to respond as positively as I can to every disaster I encounter.

Which is how we get to unemployment.

When I was informed that I had been laid off, I didn't feel surprised.  This was just as the economy was in noticeable shock of its own, and our customers had become noticeably more reticent to approve apparently-optional expenditures like web design.  We had grown rapidly the previous year, and we were now set to contract rapidly, and as one of the most junior hires, my parting stood to give the company good return for a mild loss.

I also didn't feel angry.  When the bearer-of-bad-news began to apologize, I interrupted him to say that - as outlined above - I understood the decision, that I didn't feel it reflected poorly on either of us, and that he should feel free to think of me if the situation ever reversed.

I did feel a little sad. I had enjoyed my time with the company. I had learned a great deal, and helped good people do good work. But their hands were tied, and we parted amicably, and they provided me with a good reference and excellent experience.

And for that reason, I wasn't afraid: I had been valuable enough to hire in the first place, and now, my value had been greatly enhanced by my contact with this company. Personally, I had better prospects than ever, so I wasn't worried at all.

As it happens, I'm very lucky to have the support network that I do, because as the months went by without any offers, the recession bit deeper. I still think of myself as an intelligent and valuable person (both because I am, and because thinking otherwise is counterproductive), but I've ended up spending much more time unemployed than I initially predicted.

But there have been benefits to this as well. Between sending all those applications for employment and traveling to help my father with his business, I've been able to work a great deal on a web application I've been mulling over for the past year.  Obviously, when it's finished, it can serve as the beginnings of a development portfolio, so working on it has allowed me to continue my professional growth even while not being a paid professional!

Out of vague concerns, I'm continuing to keep its name and nature secret, but I wanted to write a safely detail-free article about how I've been passing the time productively, as an encouragement both for myself and others.

But, to my mixed pleasure, before I could finish and publish it, it became outdated: I was tendered an offer for a position as an Associate Software Engineer.   I never even had the chance to show off my application!

Great news, I know, but don't think you've gotten out of hearing about my travails just because they've become less useful.

My passion for the application was sparked by learning about Google App Engine and the Python at the 2008 Google I/O developer event.  Python is a programming language that is so much fun, I'm quite annoyed I didn't learn about it before last year, Google App Engine is a framework for Python, and also a hosting service, and a framework is a collection of code that does a bunch of work for you, so you can get to the cool part of whatever-you're-making faster.  The App Engine framework in particular provides some basic extensions to Python that come in handy for making a web-based application: browser request handlers, database schema and transactions, user account validation, mild image editing, and more.

It's super-fun and, inasmuch as it connects you with the database system that makes Google search so blazing fast, quite powerful. 

My initial work sadly petered out after about a month of learning and practice, because I had become convinced that there was no way to model objects with an arbitrary number of many-to-many relationships to each other, which I saw as vital to my application.

Let me explain my perceived problem via code examples, with the names of the variables changed to protect the innocent.

Say that we want to have a database of books. Each book might have all kinds of data associated with it - ISBN, publisher name, copyright information - but we'll keep it simple for the time being.

class Book(db.Model):
  name = db.StringProperty()

The above code declares the existence of a class named "Book," based on a class named "Model" from the package "db," which contains the everything pertaining to App Engine's datastore. Book has a single property, called "name," which is declared as being of type "StringProperty," another hand-me-down from db. There are a host of different Property classes in db - for numbers of varying types, web or email addresses, files - and this one in particular will hold a string, which is short for 'string of characters,' which is short for 'a bunch of numbers, letters and/or symbols in a row.'

Let's add another property to this class: a publication date, which we might expect to be handled by the suitably-named Date property. But since each book might be published multiple times, what we really need is a list of publication dates.

class Book(db.Model):
    name = db.StringProperty()
    pubdates = db.ListProperty(datetime.datetime)

The List property expects you to put the name of a data type (like a property, but simpler) in its parentheses, so that it knows to act as a list (of zero or any positive number) of that particular type, in this case, a date.

So far, so simple. But what if we wanted to extend Book so that each book also stored the name of its author? You could just add another StringProperty, named "author," but what if you decide your app should store more information particular to each author, like a jacket photo or a short biography? Since some authors write more than one book, it would be quite annoying to store all that info on each book: for example, if you wanted to change any of it, you would have to update it in the record of every book in that author.

The solution is what App Engine calls a ReferenceProperty. First, we'll put Authors in a class all their own, and then we'll set Books to each refer to one Author.

class Author(db.Model):
    firstname = db.StringProperty()
    lastname = db.StringProperty()

class Book(db.Model):
    name = db.StringProperty()
    author = db.ReferenceProperty(Author)

As you can see, Reference properties, like List properties, want you to put the name of a class in parentheses, and forever after they can be set to link to a particular instance of that named class.

Okay, here's where the trouble began. The application I wanted to make involved a network structure, a collection of nodes, each of which might be connected to any number of other nodes.

Follow me through this painful series of failures of imagination.

class Node(db.Model):
    link = db.ReferenceProperty(Node)

This code doesn't run.

class Node(db.Model):
    refersTo = db.SelfReferenceProperty()

That code runs, because I give it the specialized Self-reference property, but it doesn't let me assign more than one link to any given node. That would still be useful for some purposes, but not mine.

class Node(db.Model):
    refersTo = db.ListProperty(Node)

This doesn't work, because Nodes are not one of the standard datatypes that List properties can use. Nor are Self Reference properties of any kind.

class Link(db.Model):
   connectsTo = db.ReferenceProperty(Node)

class Node(db.Model):
    link = db.ReferenceProperty(Link)

Maybe, if I separate out the parts of the link into two different classes, I could at least have unidirectional connections between nodes?

Wrong! This code will not run, because the second line refers to a class, Node, that isn't described until later. Obviously, the same thing happened if I reversed the position of the classes. Python has no patience when it comes to errors, which I admit is a good thing, even though it had me languishing for months, thinking my dreams were impossible.

The secret lies in the nature of Reference Properties. Each link from one object to another secretly creates a reverse link back! So, if I wanted to have a bunch of nodes connected to eachother every which way and traversible in every direction, all I need is:

class Link(db.Model):
   connectsFrom = db.ReferenceProperty(Node)
   connectsTo = db.ReferenceProperty(Node)

class Node(db.Model):
    def linksTo(self):
        return (x.connectsTo for x in self.connectsFrom_set)
    def linkedFrom(self):
        return (x.connectsFrom for x in self.connectsTo_set

The properties of Link named connectsFrom and connectsTo each create a hidden list of reference properties in the node they link to named, respectively, connnectsFrom_set and connectsTo_set. Those lists contain every link that points to that node in that way, so all we have to do is give Node a pair of methods that collect the nodes at the other end of all the links that connect to them!  Hey presto, problem solved!

It's a bit of a programming fable: A very simple change in my understanding (embarrasingly simple, actually) has opened up vast new possibilities in the design.  Once I realized what I had been missing, I wrote feverishly for several days, and eventually had perhaps three-quarters of a hideous prototype finished.

It would be wonderful to be able to show the finished product as a sign of my ability, but it would be even better to actually launch it as the service I first envisioned!  I hope that my new job will still allow me the occasional bit of free time to devote to my baby, because I honestly believe that it could be useful and fun to a lot of people.

We'll see what this year brings!

-Nick

Here's an article on Global Guerillas about the likely future resurgence of "primary loyalties" in the face of delegitimized government.

Which is to say, gangs.

Gangs are, for all intents and purposes, manufactured tribes that fill holes in governance and community networks.  They use a synthetic culture to create a new primary loyalty -- common mythology, fictive kinship, religious interpretation, etc. (in short, anything that sets them apart from everyone else).  Cohesion is maintained through a system of mutual defense, respect, and honor.  So, by extension, warfare is conducted over the same issues: encroachment, disrespect, and slights to honor.

Another good question is:  will gangs gain the substantive early mover advantages we see when scale free networks expand virally (essentially, the same process that turned a podunk site like Yahoo into a powerhouse)?  If so...
-Nick

entry.title: Dream: Chase
entry.content:
Large parking lot, row of warehouses maybe?  something bad has happened, and people are hemming and hawing over it.  far towards the entrance/exit of the parking lot, walking away, i point out a kid in a parka.  The parka's changing colors.  It's trying to blend in to the surroundings.  I notify the others and begin walking slowly towards the entrance/exit, gingerly stepping around the ice on the ground.  the kid gets on a motorcycle.  I begin running, hop on one of mine, but in the time it takes me to start it, he's roared past and around a corner.  I follow, and see he (she?) has disappeared into

entry.title: Phoo Action and the future of paying for entertainment
entry.content:
I watched this the other day.



By which I mean, I watched the pilot episode. The series wasn't picked up, and the odds of the pilot alone seeing a television or DVD release in America are exceedingly slim. So what I'm saying is you have few reasons not to download the silly thing.

The show was to be based on the ideas of Jaime Hewlett, he of Tank Girl and Gorillaz fame, and I think it shows.

Terry Phoo is a cop from Hong Kong with a cool car and no investigative skills whose kato mask seems to be an actual part of his body, and who is sent to England to help catch the people who killed the Queen, and also to transport Buddha's Loincloth, a sacred relic of unclear purpose.  In London, he encounters Whitey Action, the ambiguously-aged free-spirited red-banged daughter of the over-protective abrasively-expat-American police chief who invited Terry's assitance (you'd hope that would make him Chief Action, but unfortunately, he's named Ben Benson).

(Oh, and he's played by Carl Weathers.)


(Yeesh.  Someone get that man a lead role.  Or at least a supporting role that isn't comically racist.  At least in this, he named his daughter "Whitey".)

Anyway, Whitey thinks she can help solve the case, especially since she knows who did it (The Freebies, a gang of vicious mutants who are also beloved television personalities), and what they're planning next (kidnapping the two now-somewhat-grownup princes, who might have the funniest portrayals in the show, and this when one of the villains has a basketball for a head).  Terry decides to trust her, especially when it's revealed that she, as the chosen one, can wear and use the Buddha's Loincloth.  Buddha, you see, used it to create the universe, so while Whitey wears them (they look like athletic shorts/hot pants), she can pull anything she wants out of her crotch. Giant chocolate eggs.  Tracking devices.  Tranquilizer guns. 

So as far as I'm concerned, it was an entertaining idea with an amusingly-detailed execution (Terry's hair, Whitey's friend, Benson's dislike of clothing, everyone's slang and turns of phrase), and I recommend it.  At the very least, I think you should watch it for the sake of having an opinion: whether it's your new fave or not, it's challenging and non-standard television, which I think we can all agree is the best kind.

Well, maybe we can't all agree.  Speaking only for myself, TV sucks, meaning I don't rate much of it very high on my aesthetic scales.  But that's not too surprising, because in the business of television I, as a viewer, am not the customer, but the product; purchasers of advertising are the customers, and they want the assurance that their message will reach the demographic their marketing studies have told them are most vulnerable open to their message. 

So I have a television set, but no cable, satellelite or antenna; I use only occasionally, and only for watching dvds and playing video games.  It seems to me that if a piece of entertainment appeals to me enough that I think the creators deserve to be rewarded, even at a cost of $20-$50 to me, then I buy it.  If it seems to be worth less than that, then I torrent it and see what I think.

Harsh, right?  Actually, if there was some easier way of giving money directly to the people I think deserve to be rewarded, then I wouldn't bother buying a physical dvd ever again.  God only knows how much of the purchase price is wasted on manufacture, distribution, "licensing" and other bullshit I don't care about, but however much is left over would probably be seem a much more reasonable price to be able to give to only the artists and technicians who made it.  Why should I give any money to support distribution networks and trade-protection gangs that add no value to the work and that are looking less and less likely to survive with my cash or without it?

I suppose it could be worse: in Great Britain, they're thinking about taxing every Internet service provider as much as $40 per year per broadband connection to create a fund that would pay out to the music and movie industry.  Which would actually be great, if only in return, as with the typical laws concerning radio stations, that excepted the ISPs from having any other copyright-related claim pursued against them.  But instead, it's just an attempted kneecapping of a flourishing business model in order to inflate a dying one.

And I certainly include in that any resale or rental outlets (Ebay, Netflix, etc).  Not a single cent of the money you spend at them goes to the original artist, so they're black holes as far as I'm concerned.  If you want to save money (and money has certainly become more dear to us all, lately), then do the smart thing and don't spend any of it.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to put all my old DVDs on Craigslist.  

-Nick

entry.title: The Future is HAW!
entry.content:
As of today, I use Google Reader to follow 249 feeds and websites.  I remove some as they go defunct, or as my opinions and interests shift, and of course I add new ones as I encounter them, but in general, that's the normal number I've been following since soon after I started using the service.  Maybe the less said about my obsessive reading habits the better; I don't find reading that many to be a chore - much the opposite, in fact - but I have been annoyed by the task of sorting them into helpful categories.

Two of the outliers that both defy easy classification, yet clearly constitute a group, are John Robb's Global Guerillas and Dmitri Orlov's ClubOrlov.

John Robb is the author of Brave New War: The Next Stage of Terrorism and the End of Globalization, and the chief proselytizer of the Resilient Communities meme, which basically says that much of the world will soon be like much of Iraq - as he puts it, a "Bazaar of Violence" - and the only way you're going to have any say in your lifestyle (and, you know, life) in the future is either to engineer a an artificial tribe (a corporation and/or gang) or to design and live in a small town that is aware of its role as a source of its resident's livelihood.  Generate your own power, grow your own food, issue your own currency, all that.

So, like Ron Paul people, but not wasting time running for office or complaining about the federal reserve, etc.  He lays it out pretty simply: the interconnected markets of the world are a more reactive and complex system than any single government, or any coalition of governments that could form a practical coalition, and therefore, no government or coalition can control or re-direct it.  So hang on tight for a swift descent into a new phase of...something! 

Dmitri Orlov wrote a book called Reinventing Collapse: The Soviet Example and American Prospects
, which is basically about what advice he, as a victim of the hollowing out and looting of the Soviet Government, can give to us, future survivors of the American Collapse.  Yeah, he says it's already happening...well, yes, but he says people living in Russia at the time didn't see it coming either...well of course they tried to...now look, I don't see what my mother...FINE SURE I'M A COMMUNIST GET OVER IT.

I should also say that this book came out in June of last year and has recently, shall we say, seen it's stock rise significantly.

So, what these two sites have in common is
  1. They are both shall we say mildly pessimistic about the chances many current economic and societal structures have for survival in the coming years, much less decades. 
  2. I frequently find them both to be hilarious.  
Don't get me wrong: I believe them.  I've been convinced.  It may not happen as fast or as bad as they say, but I rate many of their predictions as above 60% likely.  But for all the bleakness and sadness I acknowledge I should be feeling, the idea, for example, that I might see in my lifetime the collapse of Northern Mexico and parts of the Southern US into narco-feudal warzones makes me completely giddy.  I start giggling.  Explanations of the expected hollowing out of nation-states make me guffaw.  I couldn't help it, and for a while, I didn't even question it.

Discussions with others (frequently started by me sharing a post in reader about, say, "international corporations successfully capturing vast state assets" with a note of, say, "HAW HAW") has gradually revealed to me that this is not a universal reaction.  They find the concept of Black Swans - events that are about to happen for the first time and therefore cannot be predicted based on previously gathered data - quite frightening.  And they should!  It's going to be terrible!  Swathes of people are going to die (elsewhere) or at best learn how to live on drastically reduced resources (here)!  How can I laugh at that?

But I do, so I was encouraged by people who I tried to share my mirth with to explain myself.

I think my problem is that, having accepted predictions of unavoidable awfulness, I feel compelled to not let it effect me unproductively.  The surprise of seeing things this way induces shock, and laughter is the noise we instinctively make when we are shocked but rapidly become convinced that we aren't in immediate danger, or that at the very least (it seems in my case) that we should try not to lose our heads just yet.

I'd be afraid of the future if it were looming behind me as I type this, but as it is instead looming over the entire world, I accept that I have to roll with the punches. It's not that the situation is humorous; humor exploits the laughter response, rather than creating it.  The situation is a communal threat that I respond to with a socially-focused quasi-distress call.  I'm trying to be aware of what a global depression would require of me, and of all the steps I can to be ready for a collapse.

But the very first thing that happens when I realize that the United States doesn't need to have a command economy to reliably produce "solutions" that just make things worse, is I start to laugh.  It's not at anyone's expense; it's just in surprise at the sudden appearance of a serious challenge that's facing all of us.

Part of the cause of this perception is that people of my age or younger, even in DC, seem to have a bias against talking too seriously with each other.  Yes, the college I attended trained its young people to talk endlessly about everything, but even in my fellow students, I saw a push towards not being a downer, towards shared frivolity.

And that's not bad.  It's just that now, I feel more inclined to share my laughter with people than what comes in the silence afterwards, the fumbling strategic planning of a young person who doesn't have any sources of information on the subject except these two doom-sayers.

Well, them and Thomas P. Barnett, author of (among others) Great Powers: America and the World After Bush, now available in better bookstores nationwide.  His is the hopeful approach.

I ended up putting all three of them in a folder informatively labeled "Future," and none in the folder labeled "Humor."

-Nick

PS: In other news, I'm still unemployed, but I remain unconcerned.  So maybe I just have a dampened danger sense/anxiety response.  But I don't think so.  I hope to discuss why in a later post.

http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090128/pdf/457528a.pdf

Completely by chance, I had tutors who brought up Plato's Syracuse misadventure, and equated The Republic with the philosophy of the Khmer Rouge.  Okay, so that was just one tutor.  The point is, it was pointed out to me that these authors were just people, and that they didn't know _nearly_ as much about the human mind and human behavior as can now be learned in a few _hours_ of reading the right books.

What I'm saying is, context would be great, and

A friend asked me a while back
What do you think is the best form of government?
and I thought my response could be an open letter.

Imagine if you instead asked me, "What do you think is the best form of life?"  My answer would be that the objective judgment is its success at maintaining a continuous line of inheritance, and that it doesn't matter what I think: what lives, lives.  But, since that's a non-answer, I'd try to give an aesthetic judgment, taking my preferences as unexamined and settling on an animal or class of animals that is, on the whole, most pleasing for me to regard.  I suspect the correct answer would be "dogs."

So, in much the same way, the best government is the one that gives rise to the most governments.  In the analogy, the history of a given country would be made of successive, slightly different generations, as each system gave rise to an altered form of itself (though the lines between generations would be hard to draw: changing administrations?  major laws passed?).  For example, the British colonies in North America aggregated, created a progeny, the constitutional congress, that replaced them, then gave rise to the republic, which gave rise to a slightly different republic, and so on and so forth, with a few forkings off as a given generation of America impregnated other countries (notably Japan 1945) via military, economic or social action (not that those are clearly delineated categories either). 

I don't have the right statistics to hazard a guess as to what forms are favored by this comparison: the CIA world factbook doesn't let me sort countries by government type.  Maybe I could write a script that would pull them in?

Anyway, as far as my personal preference, it's still tough, because Social Democracies are great, because everyone's pretty chill, and everyone's more or less taken care of.  However, it looks like the maximum enfranchisement of existing citizens leads to barriers being placed on immigration, which leads to small, insular second-class working communitees of foreigners, which naturally leads to racism: familiarity breeds familiarity, but distance fails to disprove contempt.

Let me just say that few things will ruin my aesthetic more than tribalism (racism, xenophobia, strong cultural identity, etc).  The most appealing system, for me, would foster an absolute minimum level of clade-ishness while

entry.title: Following is Leading
entry.content:
So as part of their commitment to the next-generation open social network ecosystem, Blogger has added a feature where you can "follow" other feeds.  This is much like a friends list on livejournal, except divorced from the concept of a "friend": a feed can be a person you know, or just someone you think is entertainingly crazy, or updates for software that you use, or whatever.  All updates for these feeds appear at the bottom of your blogger dashboard, much like a cramped and less useful friends page.  Luckily, they are also automatically imported to Google Reader under the tag "Blogs I follow", and reader is a feed aggregating interface I find amenable.

The advantage of "following" is that it can be done publicly.  Not only can I include a gadget showing my allegiances (an abbreviated list, in my case, since I follow nearly 200 feeds and blogs) but those.

This latter feature currently only works for blogger users, but work it does: I can follow people, and when they see me following, they can decide whether what I say is of interest to them, and begin following me.

The social web is a world of followers.

entry.title: Veteran's Day
entry.content:
Full Disclosure: I am (apparently) a veteran of a foreign war.

Yesterday my father (as always, only half-jokingly) again suggested that I could make many worse life choices than to join the Navy.  But he may have been slightly more than half-joking this time, since he immediately added that I'm one year too old to join Officer Candidacy School. 

It's just another milestone passed on the long dark highway going nowhere, another opportunity missed, scratched off life's dance card.  So what makes it particularly poignant?

Formative decisions are much more common than we can see; only a few of them are obvious.  Military service is structured and designed to make you into something unusual and impressive.  Males all dream, at least briefly, of being badasses, and the three branches (no, not five branches: Marines are Naval personnel/ordinance and the Coast Guard, while badass in their own right, don't count as military to me) are the crystallization of the resources and efforts and expertise of more generations than I can easily imagine (they pass quicker when you're being shot at) in the form of semi-functional badass factories.

I don't mean to lionize or deify these people, not least since that would be to simultaneously demonize them, as so many "uncivilized" societies clearly know, as Mark Twain taught me.





Let's ask it directly:  Who prays for soldiers?  Who prays for war?  Who prays for death to come to one stranger rather than to another?

People who want to be distinguished.  Those who actually sign up frequently want to risk more than what is typically risked, because the gains seem more attractive to them, because what they have isn't so great compared to the big heap of genetic-material-delivering muscle and hoo-ah the training can turn them into. 

That plus the slightly-less-long-term concerns of feeding and sheltering and deciding become things you no longer need to worry your pretty little head about.

That plus, for some of them, they think that some people need to die, and that their own lives are well spent being risked on that outcome.

There's any number of ways in which you can contribute to the future of your country.  There's any number of people who deserve thanks for what they did, just because it ensured the life we currently live rather than some other less fortunate one.  But veterans of foreign wars are

So there are the two big reasons to serve as I see it, as I've seen it and heard it from others:  You become someone else, which can be a good deal if you aren't so fond of your current someone, and you don't have to sweat the small stuff, the vagaries and what-comes-nexts that don't
-Nick

entry.title: Suikoden: Question and Answer
entry.content:
Recently, I've been thinking about what many folks call "Japanese-style roleplaying games," or "Japanese RPGs," or just "JRPGs."    Specifically, what makes a particular example of them "good".

(I suppose that in my own taxonomy nowadays, they'd be digital fiction games with a strongly directed story and conflict synonymous with combat.  Not quite the same ring to it.)

More prosaically: back in the day, there was the Super Nintendo, with Secret of Mana. Final Fantasy 3, Chrono Trigger, and others, and I drowned my young life in them.  It was their fault that I found Final Fantasy 7 to be such an intense disappointment.

The success of the NES had permanently embedded certain characters in the zeitgeist.  Mario.  Megaman.  Final Fantasy.  Each of these memetic complexes has their own associations and expectations.  Mario fights turtles.  Megaman is blue.  In Final Fantasy, a team of four heroes travels the world in order to save it in some way that involves crystals heavily (it was the 80s, and Japan was still in the practice of taking a decade to digest our cultural leavings).

Final Fantasy 7 was astoundingly popular.  It is one of those video games that, like Mario, was played by nearly everyone who was playing video games at the time.  This success made it genre-defining: to this day: "JRPG" effectively stands for "it's basically like Final Fantasy 7."  Everyone loved the damn thing.  I found it very disheartening.

Its first problem was unoriginality: it was exactly like every other game in the series, and completely failed to incorporate what seemed like the obvious innovations of Chrono Trigger, most notably the removing of suddden "Oh!  Now We Are Fighting!" random battles and the addition of characters that humans could care about.

Its second problem was the one innovation it could honestly claim: hideous graphics. When I heard that the Playstation represented a new generation of graphics technology, I tried to imagine the next step in the evolution diorama.

Final Fantasy 1
|
|
\/
Final Fantasy 2
|
|
\/Final Fantasy 3
|
|
\/GODDAMIT NO


I was appalled, disgusted. I had grown to expect character art to be tiny works of art, ever-increasing in complexity, and instead got a series of stiff, pointy, five-color jokes.

The picture above captures a moment which is widely regarded as the most pathos-ridden in the entire game, or even (according to idiots) in all games ever: Spikyhair McFrownyface regards the stiff, lifeless (i.e. normal) form of his realdoll-knockoff lady love, while some goth chick in the background reconnects with their lord and savior.

Not that I played as far as this purportedly-momentous point in the game. You can imagine, if this was supposed to be the pinnacle of Final Fantasy 7's emotive power, just how shitty the rest of it was.  You either didn't know what you were looking at, or it was ugly.  The characters were either uninteresting or unlikeable.  The music was either a fair adaptation of the same songs from the previous games, or not good.  Equal parts bland and bad.

I won't do the plot the disservice of calling it "incomprehensible" or "nonsensical" or "complex."  Let me assure you that games with a lot of dialogue require a great deal of writing, and when those games are made to take thirty or more hours to finish, they require a stupendous amount of words to read.  War and Peace is long, and many things happen to its characters over the course of that length: that makes it well-paced, not "convoluted."  On the other hand, if Pierre Bolkonsky had at regular intervals encountered characters entirely unconnnected to his story (yet each, shockingly, tailored to appeal to a specific target demographic) who nonetheless decide to accompany him for the rest of the book for ill-defined reasons...well, we might be briefly confused, but it won't be because we don't understand what is being done.  Final Fantasy 7 gave us a sassy underage female ninja, a mysterious emo male ninja, and a big cute cat thing.  That this trio added time to your play-through does not magically make the experience more literary.

In short, to repeat, I was disappointed.  It wasn't what I had been hoping for.

What had I been hoping for?

I wanted visually interesting fights that got out of the way as soon as I was bored with them.  I wanted to be a hero that protected people I liked from people I didn't like.  I wanted to go to strange places that were pleasing to the eye and ear.  I wanted, on occasion, to be made to laugh and to cry, but in general, to be made interested in seeing what happened next.  Seeing.  I'm not ashamed to say that, most of all, I wanted to see pretty pictures moving around on the screen.

So it turned out that what I wanted was Suikoden.

-Nick

entry.title: Suikoden: The Beginninging
entry.content:
There are three broadly recognized classics resting at the pinnacle of Asian literature: The Journey West, The Romance of the Three Kingdoms, and The Outlaws of the Water Margin.

The Journey West is about a monkey whom Buddha traps under a rock for not knowing sufficient restraint, and who later protects a priest and their friends on a pilgrimage to India.  It was the loose inspiration for Dragon Ball, an IP with generational appeal in males aged 14-24.  Dragon Ball has been a very, very long-running comic with matching television show, plus about a dozen movies, plus (most saliently) dozens and dozens of video games over the years.

The Romance of the Three Kingdoms is about the lengthy conflict of the "Warring States" period of Chinese history (or rather, the history of the geographic region which is today mostly contained within the recognized sovereign territory of the People's Republic of China).  I have lost count of the number of creative works I know that are based on the events of the novel, but we can safely stick with videogames:  There's the Romance of the Three Kingdoms series, games of strategy and tactics, where you choose a state and starting character, then try to trick, recruit and expand your way to dominance, and there's Dynasty Warriors, where you choose a character and chop your way through teeming battlefields...to dominance.  Both franchises have had a gazillion sequels.

The Outlaws of the Water Margin (or of the Marsh or of Mt. Liang or of Liangshan Marsh or even just All Men Are Brothers) is about 108 demons who are accidentally released from a demon-box and incarnate as 108 dudes who have assorted amusing adventures but eventually unite into a single band of whup-assery.  Koei made the first video game to ever be based on the story, a strategic title released in America as Bandit Kings of Ancient China.

The second was a "JRPG" called Gensou Suikoden.


Okay, if you haven't noticed it yet, that little "PAL" in the upper left corner means this is the box art for the European release, based heavily on the original Japanese box.  So yes, they got to see a watercolor crammed with awesome folks all looking out and getting ready to burst on to the world scene, including that one kid looking right at you with eyes beyond his apparent years and a half-completed gesture that says "On my command, by which I mean hitting the punk holding the box upside the head so hard they'll be be pulling his teeth out of the ceiling, unleash hell, by which I mean all 108 of you look awesome as hard as you can."

We did not see that.  This was still when the geniuses in marketing were convinced that "Americans" preferred their art to be less "arty" and more "shitty."  Witness Megaman, Street Fighter, Strider, and Suikoden.


I have no goddamn idea what is going on in this picture.  None of those people are in the game anywhere.  In fact, the only things depicted here which are in the game are:
  1. A lake.
  2. A totally sweet castle in the middle of the lake.
(Protip!  "Suikoden" is the transliteration of the way that Japanese folks pronounce the characters which are frequently translated as "Water Margin.")

So unfortunately



-Nick

Before the condolences come rushing in, I think I may have deserved it: how many times, in the past few days, have I complained about my commute?

More seriously, the bottom has certainly dropped out, and the future is far less certain.  Hooray!

Less seriously, just remember: in future, don't ever ask me where I was when we elected our first black president.

Edit:  Just to be totally clear, I was laid off, along with the other recent hires.  We were retained in the hopes of expanding the company's business, but with the recession (and yes, that's what it is), all of our clients simultaneously became much more reluctant to make outlays for web design and development work, and cuts had to be made.  It's a very regrettable situation, but I have nothing against the people who made the decision, who I still consider friends.  All of my superiors have offered me references, and I've taken up one of them on it.  I greatly value the time I spent at Blue Water Media for giving me immense experience, exposure to all kinds of skills and practices, and also for being a great time.  Not long before it happened, I confessed to my supervisor that this was by far the best job I've had yet.  I haven't revised that opinion, but I look forward to trying to match or exceed the high-water mark thus set on my next job!  Until then, I'm going to try to write, read, and also do some house chores I keep failing to finish.

entry.title: "So-Called" Bias
entry.content:
Media's Presidential Bias and Decline - ABCnews.com
The sheer bias in the print and television coverage of this election campaign is not just bewildering, but appalling. And over the last few months I've found myself slowly moving from shaking my head at the obvious one-sided reporting, to actually shouting at the screen of my television and my laptop computer.
But worst of all, for the last couple weeks, I've begun -- for the first time in my adult life -- to be embarrassed to admit what I do for a living. A few days ago, when asked by a new acquaintance what I did for a living, I replied that I was "a writer," because I couldn't bring myself to admit to a stranger that I'm a journalist.

What lily-livered nonsense.  Let's leave aside that everyone, reporters included, have a pro-winner bias, and Obama doesn't need to win to be every inch a winner, from his unshakeable sun-god gaze to promises of a new life, a new way of living as one family, one tribe...

Actually, the strength of his genuine resemblance to Christ-Mithras never really occurred to me before.  No wonder he unnerves so many avowedly Christian people: they worry that the chickens have come home to roost, that rhetoric is going to be matched with action and that they're going to be tossed out of the temple like the satanic-gospel-peddling money-changers they are.

Hmm.  I was talking about journalism.  Yeah, let's focus on that.

So leaving aside the article's obvious boo-hoo sour-grapes bias, and street-level-lionizing corner-office-demonizing bias, and, let us never forget, the corporate-sponsored bias (Did I really just link to ABC?  Will my blog ever be clean again?), all that's left is the general accusation: "A spectre is haunting the newsroom -- the spectre of bias!"  Even if this had been presented even-handedly, I would still shake my head in sorrow.  Not only is this Not News on the same level as "Professional Baseball Players Aren't Great People, Usually," or "Enforcement Doesn't Deter the Flow of Higly Demanded Goods, For Example Drugs And Cheap Labor," but it is doubly unworthy of notice, because it is using old and un-useful standards to judge the new realities of reporting.

Bias, in the guise of automatic automatic personalization, is the future of news media.

Actually, when I call it "the future," then pausing via a triumphant paragraph break and waiting for people to nod sagely (since everyone who's anyone knows how great "the future" is), reveals and fosters a bias on my part, so let me put it a better way...

Everyone wants the information they receive to be biased.

"Woah, there!  I mean, sure, lots of other people like biased media that always reinforces and never challenges their preconceived notions, but they're all ignorant hicks/elitist know-nothings/hate-plagued terrorists/zionist quislings!  I, on the other hand, am a seeker after truth!  I want balanced reporting!  I want.."

What you want is the appearance of balance, and a feeling that you are a discerning and astute person among similarly-minded people.  You want the creators of the content tagged as "news" that you consume to be good at manufacturing this appearance and sensation.  You want them to walk you through their even-handed consideration of the bare facts.  Credit where credit's due:  you are a rationalist stalwart in the fight against the rising "feelings-focused" faux-news (Distinguishing traits: asking people "how that made you feel").  I applaud and hope to share in your down-to-earth-edness.  But not everyone shares our preferences, so inasmuch as we want to hear from those who do and overlook those who don't, we seek bias: the sorting and limiting of information returned for a given topical query.

"What?  That's not what bias is!  Bias is when people let their personal feelings cloud their analysis of the truth!"

Ah, then we are talking about different things.  What you are describing is what I would call either "inaccurate," "incomplete" or "misleading" reporting, depending on the details.  Details being somewhat annoying to keep track of, many people conflate these terms into a single word, "bias," that is used to refer to any defect of journalism other than bad spelling, especially (not always) journalism that praises things that displease you and denigrates things you admire.

With sufficient discernment, the kind of "bias" you refer to can also be seen as universal: human language being what it is, there is no truly "neutral" way of presenting information.

"What do you mean, 'human language being what it is?'  Words have known connotations, and those can "

I mean that language is inherently imprecise.  In fact, the previous sentence is full of imprecision, which partially proves my point: I know exactly what I meant, but there's all kinds of ways you can take it, depending on your particular understanding of/experiences with the words "language," "inherent," and "imprecise".

Actually, tThere have been far too many attempts over the years

They are doomed to failure from the start, because

To quote James Joyce, "Other people are biased, but I am just a little set in my ways."

I am equating bias with any editorial process that limits the amount of information we receive.  You may think this is 100% fine if done by people whose editing processes you are content to call "rational" or "unbiased."  For example, Google search results are biased towards addresses with a higher page rank, which number is the result of a complex algorithm designed by people who only want you to find the best information you can want.

This bias is inescapable.  Even if you were to give equal time to all information of any kind, you would be biased towards those events which people tend to report and comment on, as well as those events that affect more people, as well as those events that are spatiotemporally co-incident with human history: events of those kinds would seem to possess greater significance than otherwise, and "significance" (according to any practical meaning) is subjective, though also useful and necessary.

Basically, if you can offer

This isn't always what they already believe (it depends on the person, and I personally love having my mind changed, since it makes me feel like I'm correcting and improving in some way), but it usually will be.  So the task of the journalist is to provide content, and the more powerful that content is (probably the higher the combined buying power of the customer base, but "buying power" is a stand-in here, since money is just a medium of exchange for power, the thing I wish I could measure), then the more successful a journalist they are.

Of course, part of the

It's another example of what I've taken to calling the "so-called" bias.  It's when you encounter a member of a class that you typically respect who, usually for vague and personal reasons, you don't like.  So you try to de-legitimize their membership, prefacing their title with "so-called " or "not a real."  For instance, I

This is also the first post I've written to this blog that started as a note to a shared item in Reader.  The process of converting the one to the other could stand to be much less painless, but I hope to do it more often

-Nick

entry.title: Travel Anxiety
entry.content:
As of this post's appearance, my flight to Anaheim (i.e., Los Angeles) is scheduled to have left Ronald Reagan National Airport.



I like travel.  I like going places.  Driving is relaxing, untaxing and generally fun.  So traveling on a plane, when you don't have to waste even that tiny fraction of your brain's processing power required to regulate a car's motion, must be even more relaxing!

You expect me to be kidding, but it is, mostly.  I find heights above twenty feet too abstract to be frightening.  Though being six-feet-plus makes me even more generally uncomfortable on a plane than you average folks are, with every ceiling too low, with no aspect of the seat in the right place to support any of my bits what need supporting...I still go to sleep just the same.  It's just discomfort, it's just time.  Babies cry, folks cough and sneeze...but that's all normal.  I share an atmosphere with you people anywhere I go.  And in any case, I've had my cold for the year.

And reaching and being in a different place, especially places that I've never been before, is always nice.  Maybe this comes from growing up in Miami, where every building, road, tree and bird seemed just so slightly inimical to human life, like we weren't supposed to stay there too long or it would be our own damn fault what happened to us.  DC is different, with folks of terrifying stability living without qualms for however long it takes, apparently waiting for this whole "federal government" fad to pass.

You might guess that I miss California, so it's lucky that's where I'm going!  Anaheim , specifically, via John Wayne Airport.


(To confirm: taking off at Reagan, landing at John Wayne.)

Besides the weather and culture, I have the further double-treat of staying with a friend who I haven't spent real time with in several years, and getting to go to Blizzcon .

You don't know my friend, or you'd be happy for just that reason, but you might have heard of the annual "fan convention" put on by Blizzard Entertainment, makers of World of Warcraft and other Very Good Games.



And even if I wasn't going to someplace I knew could be fun, I would know that I'd be fine.  I have this strange tendency to not remember any place or routine except the one I am currently inside of.  Confrontation with simultaneous evidence of different epochs at the same time (say, when I leave work on Friday and go to visit the college campus in Annapolis) makes me queasy; maybe it's a function of my generally poor memory, maybe I just want changes to stay changed, so my bizarre fluidity remains an advantage, but either way, I get the opposite of homesickness, which is what the word "homesickness" should actually mean anyway.  If I start  talking about "milksickness" or "bonesickness," you don't think that I am longing for those things, you think they have some kind of problem and I need to either avoid them or fix them!  And what's with all this looking back in the first place?  The future, the things that come next, those things are awesome, right?

That those words are a half-lie, coming from me, might be why every night before I travel farther than an hour and a half, I get so nervous I can't sleep.  I might punch and kick things, throw stuff around with strangled shouts.  I might suddenly decide to take back up running, and leave at 10 to come back at midnight.  I might decide to start driving, just pick a road and keep going until either it runs out, or I do.

I don't really know why this happens, but maybe it's because I am instinctively afraid of some potential loss.  It's so easy for me to become someone else somewhere else that whoever I am before I leave senses his death approaching.

We all die gradually, again and again, until we stop.  Each day a slightly different person wakes up in our bed than did the day before (meaning ourselves, and not counting other reasons for multiple folks passing through our beds, but if the distinction is necessary, then more power to you) until no one wakes up at all.  I guess more solid personalities are selected for on one level: if one mode of being is more likely to persist, then it's more likely for more folks to be in that mode at any given time.  I like to think that there are advantages to this flexibility, this identi-facility, but it's obvious that's only because I'm stuck with it.  Permanence has its appeal.

I'm glad to have company on this particular night before.  It helps a small bit; at least I'm not at great risk of hurting myself.

-Nick

entry.title: Now Hear This
entry.content:
Anyone who wants to ever read for free the absolutely best horror story I've ever clapped these old eyes onto should hurry, because John Dies at the End will only be available for you to click through, page after awful (meaning great) page, chapter after existentially revolting (meaning incredible) chapter for one more week.

I mean, sure, you could buy the book, the way I am going to, even though I have read the whole thing.  But then you might not be able to sit in your darkened room, lit only by lines of laconic text, punctuated by pictures of completely innocent things that may make you want to scream until you vomit.

I mean, the thing about scary books, as distinct from scary movies (and that pretty much covers the range of horrific mediums, besides hay rides and wax museums) is that they can't just jump out and booga-booga you, right?  They have to make you believe that you yourself are in danger from the threats present or implied in the text.  I've seen this done in two ways.
  1. The danger is so thoroughly described, it's as if you're experiencing it.  It's just like how sufficiently convincing images on the movie screen can frighten us even when we know they aren't tangible.  We comprehend them on an instinctive enough level that we can have instinctive responses.
  2. The danger is convincingly framed as something that genuinely menaces we the readers, as something that might have already touched our lives, or might someday, or is RIGHT BEHIND US OH GOD

Almost every Lovecraft story involves some awful revelation, a brief peek at something odd that allows the narrator to really get it, to realize that there are intelligent non-human entities that live in the ocean, or that asiatics and negroes are due to inherit the earth, or something equally "scary" (PS: Lovecraft was racist to the point of caricature).  And it's supposed to be "scary" to us, because it's being presented as an account delivered by the guy who saw it.  "You don't realize this," he says, "because it's hidden from us.  But by chance, I was able to see it.  Now you and I both know.  Oh dear.  *takes more laudanum*"

David, the pseudonymous narrator of John Dies at the End, does not take laudanum.  David drinks beer.  David's not confident enough in his command of english to make you live in his shoes.  He just wants to tell you about this stuff that happened to him and his friend John in their home town of Undisclosed. 

Stephen King sets almost all of his stories in Maine, because Stephen King lives in Maine, and his eyesight is far too poor to glean useful information about any other state, even nearby ones.  Maine is not frightening, except in as much as Stephen King lives there and is still allowed to drive, despite having killed any number of people.  Undisclosed is frightening.  Undisclosed is in the rust belt.  Undisclosed teeters on the edge of the end of western civilization, as the dehumanized, poison-spewing pain train hurtles off it's screeching rails into a hole a mile wide, shaped like a smile, from which faint screaming can be heard.  Undisclosed is very frightening.

David has lived there all his life.  David is not good at talking about his feelings, so you don't get a lot of ooh-ing and ah-ing at his intense existential anxiety.  He usually talks around it, because he doesn't want to sound like a pansy.

I like David, and I like John.  You might also.  Read it now.


-Nick

entry.title: Overheard at work: copyright debates
entry.content:
Less overheard than over-read in the notes on a given ticket.  The exchange went something like this:
Customer: Hey, thanks for those business cards files you made for us.  They're great.  But we'd like to be able to edit them.  Right now they're PDFs, so there's apparently no way to change them?  Anyway, make them something else that we can edit however we want.
Us: Yeah, you can't edit PDFs unless you buy the right software from Adobe.  So you can do that, or, if it's something small you want changed, you can tell us, and we'll bill the work at our usual rate. Incidentally, we gave you pdfs because you originally just asked for something to print directly with a minimum amount of fuss.
Customer: WTF?  We paid you for business cards, and you gave us business cards.  We own them now.  Why should we have to pay money to change something that we own?  Is this...is this a scam?  I mean, you must be joking. There's no way this is for real.

Yeah, proprietary file formats are a bitch, aren't they?  Especially when they become industry standards, like several of Adobe's properties have.  "Oh, you thought that you had the right to do whatever you want with something you bought?  Ahaha!  It is to laugh!"

Daniel has remarked in the past that he'll care about the cause of open formats when someone gives him a compelling reason to care.  Which is strange: he cares about lots of other things that have yet to affect him directly.  This one seems like a no-brainer to me.

-Nick

entry.title: Houses of the Blooded Sale and First Impressions
entry.content:
Most roleplaying games are designed with cheaters, wankers and munchkins in mind. Designers put in place to keep those people from abusing loopholes. After all, this is a roleplaying game. Loopholes exist. So, instead of putting so many limits on the players that they can’t even breathe, I’ve done the opposite. I’ve put the power directly into your hands. Again, you may ask, why would I do such a thing?

Because I trust you.

I trust that you understand it isn’t just the Narrator’s job to make sure everybody’s having fun. It’s everybody’s job to make sure everybody is having fun.

That was John Wick, creator of the roleplaying games Legend of the Five Rings and 7th Sea, from the "Players" chapter of his brand new roleplaying game, Houses of the Blooded.  So now that you've met him, maybe now you understand me when I say that, when John Wick tells you that for a limited time only, you can get the pdf of his brand new roleplaying game, Houses of the Blooded, for only five stinkin' bucks, then you don't think about it, you buy the damn thing.

And by you, I mean "I and maybe you too."

From my skimming once-over, it's excellent.  It's Vampire meets Birthright.  Or at least, it's the meeting of what I wanted those games to be.  Rules for personal passion and tragedy, rules for managing and expanding your holdings.  I deem it to be "the hype."

The core innovation on top of the Fate system is the concept of "wagers."  Simply:
  1. Get dice (6-sided) from one stat and some aspects.
  2. Choose how many of those dice you roll, and how many you instead "wager".
  3. Sum results of rolled dice.  Greater than 10 is "success".  Say how you do or do not accomplish (your choice) what was being tested.
  4. If you succeeded, state one more fact about the action for each wager you made.
Basically, the camera rests on characters when they are doing what they are good at.  Also, it explicitly turns "Gather Information" rolls into "Establish as Fact Whatever You Think Would Be Advantageous or Cool" rolls.  Awesome.

No list of skills means ability in a given field (there are six) is broadly applicable, so characters (presumably) feel extremely capable.  But they also have a weakness, which is nearly absolute; you receive no dice in one of the six kinds of rolls.  Other games talk about "tragic flaws," but this one cuts a hole in your armor and rings the dinner bell for your enemies.

Yet another game to file under "Would Like to Play Sometime."  Sigh.

-Nick

entry.title: Homes for Heroes
entry.content:
City of Heroes is a game I played once. If you aren't familiar, it's World of Warcraft, but you're a superhero in (I swear) an alternate universe Rhode Island. It was fun.

It is, to put it mildly, well-supported. Besides the usual problem fixes, the designers regularly release Issues: large packs of entirely new quests, events, and game concepts. You'd log in and now your hero could have a cape, or wings, or a hideout. Gadgets were introduced as a new kind of power-up item. Entirely new sets of powers for your superheros to use were created.

Today Reader brought my attention to this post on the game's upcoming 13th issue.

Actually, I had heard about it before. Specifically, I had heard that this patch will allow players to create missions, quests, for other players. I think that's a feature that will go from "No game does it except for that one weird one" to "every game has that in some form unless they suck" in record time.

But what I hadn't heard of was this secret identity stuff. Good grief. It is:

1) An absolutely brilliant way for a game to support the the conventions of the genre. "Now that I've fought crime, I've got to get back to the Local Newspaper offices before anyone notices I'm gone!"
2) Yet another feature that no one else thought of and will soon become standard.

Long before "user-generated content" was a buzzword, it was a simple fact. Ultima Online had a persistent game world where the players could own land and build houses. This didn't seem revolutionary at the time. In fact, UO's property system was extremely limited compared to that of almost any text-based MUD you'd care to look at. People who played these things expected to be able to have houses. Otherwise, they'd be homeless! How terrible!

And yet nowadays, good 3-d art assets being so terribly time consuming to make, not many games let players own and customize property in-game. All those gorgeously kitted-out warriors of the Alliance, veterans of every great conflict in Azeroth? Homeless. Destitute veterans wearing and carrying immense fortunes.

I admit that this bothers me. Armor and weapons and history make you a wandering ex-soldier. Property, renown, effect on the game world, these things make you powerful. Or at least feel powerful in a virtual context.

Final Fantasy 11, Granado Espada and, as I understand it, City of Heroes, use a system where an instance is created that claims to be, respectively, your imaginary apartment, family mansion, and hideout. But no one can encounter these places in the normal course of play: They're abstracted out. No one can go there except you and people you invite, meaning no one can discover it, no one can encounter it, just as they encounter Horn Mountain or the Well of Souls or all the other locations of the shared fiction. No one is talking about that cool place where you live. But despite this fugue-state-esque privacy, there's nothing unique or special about your home: They all occupy the same basic imagined location in the game world, since the entrances to these spaces are the same for everyone. Everyone's apartment is down that street. Everyone's mansion is behind these gates. (I don't know if the Hideouts in City of Heroes are guilty of this too.)

This change means that your hero doesn't have to disappear just because you stop playing. You can know where he is. He builds a connection to a place that anyone can see, where everyone walks past. He binds himself to the fabric of the fiction.

Super-cool.

-Nick
